 BODY:
President Bush will use an economic conference in Thailand later this month as the jumping-off point for a weeklong trip to Asia and Australia. 
 The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum will takes Mr. Bush to Bangkok, Thailand, on Oct. 20-21, the White House announced on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: THE CALIFORNIA RECALL: THE PRESIDENT; 
Bush Plans Appearance With Schwarzenegger

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
President Bush will appear at the side of California's governor-elect, Arnold Schwarzenegger, during a fund-raising trip to the state next week, a Republican close to the White House said on Wednesday, even as some religious conservative supporters of Mr. Bush said they were troubled by accusations that Mr. Schwarzenegger had engaged in sexual misconduct. 
 But the conservatives said their concerns would not spill over to Mr. Bush. It was unthinkable, they added, that a Republican president would not stand with a newly elected Republican governor on a trip to the state, particularly one the White House hopes to win in 2004. 
 "The president is a politician who is running for re-election, and given that California could be the key to 2004 and that the vote was resoundingly for Arnold I don't think the president feels he is embracing Arnold in all of his manifestations," said Robert Knight, the director of the Culture and Family Institute, a Washington conservative group.
White House advisers pronounced themselves elated with the election's outcome, and insisted that the accusations that Mr. Schwarzenegger had groped women were politically motivated. The accusations would not, they said, affect Mr. Bush, who has made conservative family values a part of his political appeal. 
"This is a sea change in California," a Republican close to Mr. Bush's top political advisers said. "The people have rejected attack politics, so I don't think you'll see anything but support for the new Republican governor."
Mr. Bush called Mr. Schwarzenegger on Wednesday to offer congratulations, said Scott McClellan, the White House press secretary. Next Wednesday or Thursday, Mr. Bush is to appear with Mr. Schwarzenegger in Fresno or Riverside, between fund-raisers for his re-election campaign. 
Many Republicans have said for weeks that Mr. Schwarzenegger's victory would give Mr. Bush a strong organizational and fund-raising foundation in a traditionally Democratic state. Democrats, and some Republicans close to Mr. Bush, have countered that Gov. Gray Davis, the unpopular incumbent Democrat who was ousted on Tuesday, would have been an ideal foil for Mr. Bush and might have inspired high turnout among Republicans.
Mr. Schwarzenegger, they added, will be of little help to Mr. Bush's re-election if he proves unable to handle the state's financial crisis that was a major factor in Mr. Davis's defeat.
White Houseadvisers said that Mr. Bush had favored Mr. Schwarzenegger in the recall effort, though he was loath to say so publicly to avoid accusations of meddling in the election. Mr. Schwarzenegger was known as a loyal friend of the Bush family who had campaigned for the first President Bush. 
Former President Bush returned the favor, Mr. Schwarzenegger said, with a $1,000 contribution to his campaign for governor.
On Wednesday night, the current President Bush collected $14 million at a fund-raising dinner for the Republican National Committee at the Washington Hilton. At the dinner, donors could give the party up to $25,000, the annual maximum allowed by law. The money can be used for television advertising for Mr. Bush and other Republican candidates.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Are Insisting Money for Iraq Be Loans 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
In the last week or so, Representative Zach Wamp, a conservative Republican from Tennessee, has said no to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, to Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, and to Joshua B. Bolten, the White House budget director. 
 And on Wednesday, when President Bush summoned him to the White House to say that Iraq must be given $20.3 billion in reconstruction money, Mr. Wamp also said no. Like a growing number of Republicans in the House and Senate, he wants the administration to lend rather than give all the money to Iraq, and he is unafraid of defying the White House on the subject. 
 "Obviously we've got their attention on this one," he said. "But I think we're doing the right thing, and I respectfully take issue with them. And believe me, the people of Tennessee are cheering me on as we do this."
Members of Congress from around the country say they are underintense pressure from their constituents to scale back the nation's generosity to Iraq at a time when domestic unemployment and deficits are at high levels. The idea of granting money to Iraq with no hope of repayment has become particularly unpalatable for many lawmakers, several of whom have written amendments that would require some form of a loan.
A few of the measures are vague on the nature and terms of a loan, but others are explicit that Washington must eventually be reimbursed. The White House has been negotiating with some members on the exact language of the amendments, a move that is seen on Capitol Hill as an indication that the administration recognizes the depth of public concern about the reconstruction money.
"My constituents are proud of this president, but they are as adamant as I am that we want our money back for reconstruction, just like we were promised," said Representative John A. Culberson, Republican of Texas, an old ally of the president from their Austin days, who planned to propose a loan amendment but dropped it Wednesday under pressure from the White House. 
Mr. Wamp, a member of the House Appropriations Committee, plans to introduce loan amendments at Thursday's committee meeting that would give half the $20.3 billion to Iraq immediately, and would lend the rest once some form of permanent Iraqi government is established. 
Opponents of the loan plans -- who include Republican leaders supporting the president's position and some liberal Democrats -- say that some of the amendments are simply intended to make reconstruction more palatable for constituents without really diminishing America's role.
"I think a number of these amendments are designed to essentially appeal to politics back home," said G. William Hoagland, budget director for the Senate majority leader, Bill Frist. "They won't change the fact that we still have to appropriate the money, and that there really isn't a government entity in Iraq right now that anyone can lend money to." Administration officials told the House Armed Services Committee Wednesday that a loan would remove American control over the reconstruction.
Representative Rahm Emanuel, an Illinois Democrat who has been critical of the reconstruction plan, said the loan provisions would backfire once the public learned that the United States would be last in line to be repaid, behind creditors like Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, France and Russia, which together are owed $200 billion. Other House Democrats, including Representative Jan Schakowsky of Illinois, said Wednesday that they planned to oppose the entire $87 billion spending bill for Iraq and Afghanistan that includes the reconstruction money.
The chairman of the appropriations committee, Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, predicted that all the loan amendments would be defeated, but Republican officials said similar plans had a strong chance in the Senate. One Senate proposal that has gained significant bipartisan support would require that half the $20.3 billion be repaid, but would allow that amount to be forgiven if Iraq cannot make such a payment.
"If Iraq isn't successful in rebuilding the economy, then we wouldn't expect them to return the money," said the amendment's sponsor, Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas.
The White House has worked hard to get Republicans to drop or weaken their proposals, inviting several members to meetings with the president or other top officials to get them to change their mind.

HEADLINE: Putin's Democratic Present Fights His K.G.B. Past 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
There is a question that irritates President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, and it is the one about his past as a foreign intelligence operative of the K.G.B.
 "They cannot forget about that agency," he replied, seemingly to his aides, when asked a version of it in an expansive interview at his wooded presidential estate outside of Moscow. He chuckled, but not warmly. 
 Does the president of a newly democratic Russia -- or, as some say, an increasingly autocratic one -- regret any part of the K.G.B.'s history? 
"No, of course not," he said brusquely and, surprisingly, personally. "There was absolutely nothing that I could be ashamed of." 
The question, and his answer, lie at the heart of today's Russia, because fairly or not, much of what is happening here is viewed through the prism of Mr. Putin's first career: the war in Chechnya, government control of news organizations and elections, the growing role of former security officers like himself in all ranks of government. 
But there is another side to Mr. Putin, too, the one molded by his second, post-Soviet career as an apparatchik in a democratic, reformist government of St. Petersburg, the city built as Russia's "window to Europe" and the birthplace of the revolution that slammed the window shut after 1917. 
"We remember, and we are obliged to remember, everything negative, everything horrible that we encountered in the 20th century," Mr. Putin said. "We should draw conclusions from this. We have paid a very great price for this. Millions of people died in the camps. The totalitarian regime brought the country to a national catastrophe and to the collapse of the Soviet Union. And we are fully aware of this, and the people of Russia have drawn conclusions for themselves."
And so, he ended, "We firmly stand on the path of development of democracy and of a market economy."
After meeting him for the first time in 2001, President Bush famously said he had looked into Mr. Putin's eyes, got "a sense of his soul" and liked what he saw. To most Russians, Mr. Putin's "soul" remains a far more complicated, conflicted question.
A wealthy businessman who is close to him -- and spoke anonymously to remain that way -- said there were in fact two Putins, a security agent and a democrat, struggling for equipoise. Or as Viktor Erofeyev, a writer who was and still is something of a dissident, put it: Mr. Putin has "a dark angel" on one shoulder and "a light angel" on the other.
In the four years since Russia's first president, Boris N. Yeltsin, plucked him from political obscurity and anointed him the second, Mr. Putin has steered Russia onto a stable, democratic and Western-looking path that he said was irreversible, if still incomplete. 
At the same time, he has overseen what his critics call a steady erosion of democratic rights.
His press ministry closed the last independent national television network in June and gave its frequency to a government-owned sports channel. His government pushed through new election rules this summer that, taken literally, prohibit media coverage of candidates and anything they say or do. 
Russia, 12 years after the collapse of the Soviet state, still has an opaque judicial system. It still has closed cities, where foreigners and even most Russians cannot go. Its security services again wieldsignificant power.
The businessman said Mr. Putin's conflicting instincts -- between freedom and state -- mirror the struggle within his government and country. This struggle will dominate his second term, his re-election next March being considered a given. While the outcome could determine the country's course, he said Mr. Putin himself might never resolve it. 
"I believe that the struggle within Putin will go on until the end of his life," he said.
In person, Mr. Putin comes across as exceedingly disciplined and concentrated. His office at the compound in Novo-Ogaryovo, a stylish suburb of Moscow, reflects a focus on power, not its trappings. It is ornate, but sparsely decorated.
The president, who turned 51 on Tuesday, listens intently and builds lengthy, meticulously constructed answers. He has a strong command of detail and a sense of humor, albeit a sardonic one.
The interview, which took place Saturday, was conducted in Russian and English, through a translator, with Mr. Putin occasionally interjecting in English.
At several points, he sought to draw moral equivalencies between Russia and the United States in the same way Soviet leaders once did -- and as before, some were simply strained. 
He avoided a direct question about the growing influence of the security officials -- known as siloviki -- by saying he had simply restructured law enforcement agencies the way the Bush administration created the Department of Homeland Security. "To talk about a return to the Soviet times in connection with would be like talking about the times of McCarthy, referring to the ministry of homeland security in the United States," he said. "This is rubbish that has nothing to do with reality."
Of his own service in East Germany in the last years of a dying Soviet empire, he expressed pride. He derided "various cliches and labels" -- presumably meaning those applied to him -- as "very ineffective" and "even primitive."
"You know, we haven't fallen from the moon," he said at another point of those who, like him, served in the security services. "We were born in this country. We live here. We are products of the time in which we lived. That is a fact."
The Communist Party of the Soviet Union -- and the secret services that kept it in power -- represented the state itself, intertwining "more than 20 million people," including himself, into its bureaucracy but not necessarily into its historic culpability, he argued.
"And what now -- must all of these 20 million people cover their heads in ash and whip themselves?" he said.
Referring to Mr. Yeltsin, he said: "The former president, the first president of Russia, was a member of the Politburo of the Central Committee. Meanwhile, he probably is the person who has done the most important thing in the contemporary history of the country. He gave it freedom."
That is the essence of Mr. Putin. He, like Russia, he has sought to reconcile the past and the future. He portrays himself as part of a new generation, one shaped by the past, but looking forward.
Addressing the issue more directly perhaps than he ever has, Mr. Putin described what he called the "very harsh, black periods" of Soviet history -- the Stalin-era purges. He acknowledged that the "state security apparatus served as the main tool of these repressions." At the same time, however, he insisted the security services that became the K.G.B. he worked for were only a tool wielded by the controlling hands of the real power, the Communist Party. 
"This was in the 1930's -- in the last century -- but continued practically until the death of Stalin in 1953," he said. "I will draw your attention to the fact that I was born in 1952."
Mr. Putin noted that he had studied law at St. Petersburg University, an institution known, he said, for "its democratic traditions." He also studied a foreign language, German, and is learning English now. Perhaps because of that, perhaps because his roots lie in "a window to Europe," he spoke of a vision of Russia closely intertwined with Europe, economically, socially and politically. 
He does not ascribe to theories of Russia's unique Eurasian character -- nor of a Russian claim of exclusivity when it comes to establishing democratic freedoms.
"By their mentality and culture, the people of Russia are Europeans," he said. 
Mr. Putin curtly dismissed the notion that his -- and Russia's -- commitment to democracy was still somehow wavering, even as he frankly acknowledged shortcomings in elections and press freedoms. 
"Of course many things are still in a stage of evolution," he said. 
When he first came to power, he said he hoped to create a "dictatorship of law," a phrase that received more attention for the first word rather than the last. In the interview, he said the most important lesson from his education was "respect for the law."
Whether Mr. Putin adheres to that lesson, and whether the rest of Russia embraces it, remains to be seen. Russia is a place where corruption is rife and where few share a sense of civic responsibility. 
Mr. Putin clearly desires order, and to him that means a strong central government. Asked about reports that ExxonMobil was negotiating to buy a large share of the newly merged YukosSibneft, Russia's largest oil company, Mr. Putin said Russia welcomed foreign investment. Then he added that the government ought to have a say in so significant a deal. 
"I think it would be the right thing to do to have preliminary consultations with the Russian government on this matter," he said. 
On Tuesday, an official in Mr. Putin's government amended his remarks, the Interfax news agency reported, saying there was in fact no legal obligation requiring any foreign investor to consult the government.

HEADLINE: Dean Says President Bush Is Setting the Stage for the 'Failure of America' 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
Howard Dean, a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, on Wednesday offered perhaps his most overarching critique yet of the Republican incumbent, saying, "I think what the president is doing is setting the stage for the failure of America."
 "If you look at what's happened to other great countries," Dr. Dean said over lunch with reporters and editors of The New York Times, "they get in trouble when they can't manage their money -- and this president's certainly proven himself adept at that -- and they get in trouble when they overstretch their military capabilities." 
 "This country's a great country, and the reason it's an important country is not just because I'm an American and proud to be an American," he continued. "America is the beacon of hope for the rest of the world. We are the last country on earth where cynicism doesn't pervade government. Americans really hope that things are going to get better in the world and they can make things better, and Americans believe more than any other people that we can make things better by sheer will and money and hard work." 
Dr. Dean said he expects jobs to be the primary issue in next year's general election, and he expects Ohio to be the critical swing state. But he spent most of the interview answering questions about foreign policy, attacking President Bush on Iraq and North Korea and promising to send former President Bill Clinton to the Middle East as a peace broker.
President Bush, Dr. Dean said, is "particularly poorly suited" for foreign policy "because he has a black and white view of the world, and foreign policy depends on enormous understandings of nuances and trade-offs."
As the former governor of Vermont who got a medical deferment to avoid service in Vietnam, Dr. Dean said he would combat criticism of his national security bona fides by surrounding himself with people who could inspire confidence in such issues. 
Though he declined to speculate on cabinet appointments or potential running mates, Dr. Dean, who has lately spent much time attacking his Democratic rivals as Washington insiders who have, collectively, spent more than a century on Capitol Hill, said he would also pick people who could navigate the Beltway.
"The most important criteria for whether you're going to be any good at foreign policy or not is judgment and patience, both of which are in short supply in this presidency." Dr. Dean said. "The major mistake that governors make when they come into Washington is they think subconsciously that the relationship between the Congress and the president is somehow like the relationship between the legislature and the governor," he added, predicting that "getting someone who understands the levers of power in Washington is going to be important as well."
Regarding Iraq, Dr. Dean, who opposed the American invasion this spring, promised to bring National Guard and Army reserve troops home, leaving 70,000 American troops, and to add about 110,000 international troops, mostly from Muslim and Arab nations. Some experts say that is probably unrealistic, considering the military capabilities of American allies in the Middle East.
Other than urging repeal of recent tax cuts to pay for reconstruction, Dr. Dean refused to say how he would vote, were he in Congress, on the $87 billion financing proposal. 
"I'm not running for Congress, I'm running forpresident," he said.
 On North Korea, Dr. Dean said Mr. Bush had bungled the situation by announcing at a news conference with Kim Dae Jung, the former president of South Korea, that he planned to pursue a policy of isolation toward North Korea. While the news conference was not as explicit as Dr. Dean described, Mr. Bush and the South Korean leader split sharply on Korea policy at that meeting early in Mr. Bush's presidency, and their relationship never recovered.
Dr. Dean said he would conduct bilateral negotiations on the principle of constructive engagement -- "that in return for a verifiable ending of their nuclear program," he explained, "they would be back in the community of nations."
"You will improve the behavior of rogue nations and have more leverage to do so if they're inside the tent than if they're outside the tent," he said. "The president and his neocon advisers decided they were going to teach the North Koreans a lesson, and unfortunately, North Korea has the power to inflict a fairly painful lesson on us." 
Dr. Dean declined to discuss the other Democratic rivals except to say "they all come from Washington, which I think, this year, is going to be a problem for them." Though he said it was too early to draw broad lessons from the California recall, he said the message is change which he painted as positive for his campaign.
"My strategy is, we're better than this, we can do better than this," he added. "America's always been the country of hope and of high moral principles and ideals. Let's hope again."

An article on Thursday about Howard Dean's candidacy for the Democratic presidential nomination and his assertion that President Bush is "setting the stage for the failure of America" referred incompletely to the medical deferment Dr. Dean received during the Vietnam War. While he did indeed request a physical examination, he said he did so after receiving a low number in the draft lottery, to determine his options for the military, not explicitly to avoid service.

HEADLINE: THE CALIFORNIA RECALL: THE BALLOTING; 
Signaling Voter Unrest, Schwarzenegger Cut Deep Into the Democrats' Base

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and MARJORIE CONNELLY 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
Arnold Schwarzenegger pulled together a vast coalition of dissatisfied voters from across all demographic groups in California's recall election on Tuesday, winning among all age groups and, perhaps most ominously for Democrats, appearing to make inroads into their traditional base, surveys show.
 In a major sign of voter unrest in this Democratic bastion, one-quarter of the people who identified themselves as Democrats voted to recall Gov. Gray Davis, a Democrat, and 18 percent voted for Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican. 
 Mr. Schwarzenegger also won 31 percent of Hispanic voters and 17 percent of black voters, doing significantly better with both groups than did Bill Simon Jr., the Republican candidate for governor in 2002.
And despite the last-minute accusations about unwanted sexual advances toward women, Mr. Schwarzenegger narrowed the gender gap that Republicans traditionally face, winning the votes of 49 percent of the men who voted and 43 percent of the women.
The numbers are based on interviews with nearly 4,000 voters as they left the polls conducted by Edison Media Research and Mitofsky International for The New York Times and other news organizations.
In fact, Mr. Schwarzenegger did almost as well with women as Mr. Davis, as measured by the 49 percent of women who supported the Democrat by voting against his recall.
More women tend to be Democratic than Republican, and this is particularly true in California, an overwhelmingly Democratic state. Here, only 36 percent of women describe themselves as Republican, and 71 percent of them voted for Mr. Schwarzenegger. So did 20 percent of Democratic women.
Mr. Schwarzenegger won pluralities of women in all age groups. He did the worst with women under 30, but still got 41 percent of their votes. His strongest supporters were men ages 30 to 44.
In addition, Mr. Schwarzenegger demonstrated enough strength to fend off any criticism that he had become governor with only a minority of the vote. Even with 135 candidates on the ballot, Mr. Schwarzenegger won more votes in favor of his candidacy (4,358,000, with 99.8 percent of the votes counted) than Mr. Davis won against the recall effort (3,541,000). And that was more than the 3,533,490 votes Mr. Davis won last November, when he was re-elected to a second term.
Combining Mr. Schwarzenegger's votes with those for another Republican, State Senator Tom McClintock, about 60 percent of those who voted on Tuesday did so for Republicans -- possibly good news for the White House, which now has plausible reasons to see California as up for grabs in 2004, although President Bush's approval ratings in California are at 51 percent, no better than the rest of the country (but no worse, either). Mr. Bush is scheduled to meet with Mr. Schwarzenegger next week.
"The Schwarzenegger campaign excited Republicans, Hispanic voters and union-member households," said Ed Gillespie, chairman of the Republican National Committee. "The Democrat Party and the Democrat presidential candidates should take heed."
Democrats looking for any signs of hope might find them in the fact that Mr. Schwarzenegger's weakest support was among people with advanced degrees and people making less than $50,000 a year. And his assertion during the campaign that he would draw new voters into the party did not materialize significantly. Only 3 percent of voters said they had never voted before, and another 3 percent said they rarely voted. Of those two groups of voters, Mr. Schwarzenegger won about half of them.
The surveys also showed that more than two-thirds of the voters had made up their minds more than a month before the election. As a result, the intense publicity in the last week of the campaign about accusations of Mr. Schwarzenegger's unwanted sexual advances appeared to have had little effect on how women -- and others -- voted.
Surveys indicate that the sputtering economy remains an overriding concern for California voters.
A full 83 percent said the economy was in bad shape. That number shows a serious erosion of confidence in the state's economic health since Governor Davis was re-elected 11 months ago. At that time, 47 percent perceived the economy to be in bad shape, according to a survey by The Los Angeles Times.
Various surveys have shown that a vast majority of voters believe the state is on the wrong track, an important signal of discontent in electoral politics, and that voters have been alarmed about the state's plunging credit rating, the exodus of more than 100,000 manufacturing jobs and a budget deficit of billions of dollars.
The surveys also suggest that Mr. Davis misinterpreted the economic anxiety in his state or did not appreciate it. This was evident in his signing of a bill to allow illegal immigrants to get drivers' licenses, a move that the survey found was opposed by 70 percent of voters. Interviews with voters have shown that many Californians perceive the drivers' license issues as less a social issue than an economic one. By giving licenses to illegal immigrants, many voters say, the state would attract more illegal immigrants who would be a drain on already strained resources like schools. Mr. Davis had vetoed the measure twice before signing it this summer.

How the Poll Was Conducted
The poll of voters was based on questionnaires completed by people on Tuesday as they left polling stations throughout California. Questionnaires were offered in English or Spanish.
The poll was conducted by Edison Media Research of Somerville, N.J., and Mitofsky International of New York City.
The results are based on 3,814 voters in 60 randomly selected precincts across California, interviewed as they were leaving voting places.
In addition, 400 self-identified absentee voters, reached at random telephone numbers, were also interviewed, and their results have been added to the poll. 
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results from such polls should differ by no more than plus or minus two percentage points from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview everyone who cast a ballot in the recall election.
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion at polling places, like the reluctance of some voters to take time to fill out the questionnaire, may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: THE CALIFORNIA RECALL: THE GOVERNOR-ELECT; 
Seizing the Moment, and Defying Expectations

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 8 

 BODY:
Perhaps Jay Leno was right. "Tonight is a testament to just how important one appearance on the 'Tonight Show' can be," he said on Tuesday night, before introducing Arnold Schwarzenegger at his victory party.
 Every campaign has what is called "the moment," the convergence of events where a candidate is either built or broken. For Mr. Schwarzenegger, that moment may well have been his surprise Aug. 6 announcement of his candidacy on Mr. Leno's "Tonight Show." 
 For all the high-priced professionals that Mr. Schwarzenegger employed to give him a cram course in politics -- he spent more than $10 million of his own fortune for the campaign -- it was his flair for the dramatic, his larger-than-life personality and his preference for big-production campaign events that seemed, more than anything else, to lead him to this extraordinary place in history. 
It was widely thought that Mr. Schwarzenegger was going to announce that evening that he would not enter the recall race, admitting that he needed two years to study the crosscurrents of California before taking a run at the governor's office. He held his cards so close to the vest that even his most intimate advisers and a close friend, Richard J. Riordan, the former mayor of Los Angeles, did not know of his decision. 
His chief strategist, George Gorton, stood backstage at the taping of the Leno show holding a news release that explained the actor's decision to stay out. Instead, Mr. Schwarzenegger said he was in, inflaming a media frenzy that American politics has seldom seen.
"I have to admit I felt embarrassed," Mr. Gorton said later. "But he didn't tell anyone. It was a masterstroke in political theater. The only problem was, it put us behind the eight ball. We had no organization put together to carry the ball from that moment."
He suffered for the humor. It was not the stuff of serious politics, his critics complained. His campaign stumbled through the first two weeks as a staff was cobbled together and as Mr. Schwarzenegger was subjected to seminars on issues from water policy to workers compensation.
The expectations for a vigorous and entertaining campaign that Mr. Schwarzenegger engendered with his announcement began to erode his credibility when he retreated from public view. The news media portrayed him as an actor on a vanity project and a badger hiding in his hole.
"We got out of the gate slowly because we didn't have a team in place," Mr. Gorton said.
The introduction of Mr. Schwarzenegger the politician came three weeks later when he assembled a group of advisers including Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor, and George P. Shultz, the former secretary of state, for an economic policy forum. It proved a defining day for the neophyte candidate. He had finally added some heft, even if it was rented, to a campaign that until then was running solely on celebrity.
As he addressed reporters that day, a few important lessons were learned. For one, Mr. Schwarzenegger found the voice and cadence he would employ on the stump. "I feel the people of California have been punished enough," he said in a rehearsed statement. "From the time they get up in the morning and flush the toilet they're taxed. When they go get a coffee they're taxed. When they get in their car they're taxed. When they go to the gas station they're taxed. When they go to lunch they're taxed. This goes on all day long. Tax. Tax. Tax. Tax. Tax."
With each punctuation, the flash bulbs fired in syncopation, and Mr. Schwarzenegger's physical stature swelled before the cameras. His chunky English charmed and the details of policy quickly drifted away. 
Something else was learned there too. Forget the garish suits. Wear conservative ties. No more alligator shoes. Stick to the script. No ad-libs. 
When asked for specific budget cuts, he said, "The public doesn't care about figures."
That line brought ridicule from academics and editorial writers, and caused his aides to cringe. But, as Mr. Schwarzenegger said, the public did not seem to care.
Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, marveled at Mr. Schwarzenegger's avoidance of specifics and his ability to get away with it. "You hold a press conference and you answer their questions," Ms. Feinstein said. "If you don't answer their questions, they let you know it. That didn't happen this time." 
She added: "He was able to insulate himself and maybe that is what is reserved for celebrity and really not for the rest of us. He did not have one specific program outside the car tax as far as I know."
The strategy in the Schwarzenegger camp came to be known as "Let Arnold Be Arnold." 
A senior Schwarzenegger adviser, Todd Harris, said that the campaign deliberately avoided most interviews with mainstream news organizations, preferring instead the more gentle ministrations of Oprah Winfrey and Larry King.
"A lot of thought was given to the idea that we had the ability to expand upon the traditional outlets that tend to cover politics and take our message directly to a segment of the population that frankly isn't the 'Meet the Press' crowd," said Mr. Harris, who was an adviser to the 2000 presidential campaign of Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona. "Because of who our candidate was, we could take advantage of that."
Peter Ragone, who directed news media strategy for Governor Davis's effort to battle the recall, said that Mr. Schwarzenegger could afford to run a cautious campaign. 
"He didn't do too much, but he didn't have to," Mr. Ragone said. "Because of the role celebrity plays in our society, people had an image of him. He had unlimited financial resources to maintain that perception. And he had a deep economically driven anxiety among the electorate that left the people of the state hungry for change. And so to the extent they ran a campaign that didn't upset any of those things, it was successful."
Though Mr. Schwarzenegger is famously disciplined, he occasionally strayed from his script and made statements his spokesmen had to erase. On the "Tonight Show," Mr. Schwarzenegger said he had "plenty of money myself" and did not need to accept contributions from others. As large amounts of cash from corporations and wealthy individuals began pouring into the campaign, Mr. Schwarzenegger amended his comment to say that he would not take money from "special interests," which he defined as labor unions and Indian tribes that operated casinos. They were not contributing to his campaign in any event.
He spoke of closing down the state Environmental Protection Agency. His aides were dispatched to tamp out the fires.
The apex of his campaign came in his only debate, in Sacramento. He skipped all the other candidate forums and debates, saying he was saving himself for the "Super Bowl," which also happened to be the only debate in which the questions were provided in advance.
His aides said that evening that all he needed to do was string a noun, a verb and a few statistics together to address any lingering concerns about his competence and cement his victory. 
The actor did a bit more than that, reciting the lines a joke writer had written for him. When Arianna Huffington goaded him on the similarity of his views to those of President Bush, for instance, Mr. Schwarzenegger said, "Arianna if you want to campaign against Bush, then go to New Hampshire." That provoked a few laughs. Then he told her, "You need a little more decaf."
After the debate, Mr. Schwarzenegger surged in the polls, padding his lead over his only credible challenger, Lt. Gov. Cruz Bustamante, a Democrat.
Mr. Harris said Mr. Schwarzenegger had met the minimal requirements of the debate, presenting a vision for the state without getting bogged down in facts or a dispute over how to balance the budget.
"Vision will trump specifics eight days a week in a campaign," he said. 
With the debate safely behind him, Mr. Schwarzenegger embarked on the final leg of his star turn, a bus tour planned by Mr. Harris and Mike Murphy, the strategists who conceived the McCain "Straight Talk Express" bus tour of 2000. He drew tremendous and enthusiastic crowds across the state, even as Mr. Davis was speaking to tepid gatherings at union halls and schools. 
The night before the tour was to start, however, the cellphones of Mr. Schwarzenegger's senior staff members began to buzz. The Los Angeles Times had just posted on its Web site a long article detailing the accusations of six women that Mr. Schwarzenegger had sexually manhandled them, charges that were familiar but had remained muted during the previous weeks of the campaign. At 6:45 a.m., the candidate's news staff conferred by conference call about how to respond, even though they had not heard Mr. Schwarzenegger's explanation for the incidents. They agreed that some public acknowledgment and apology was probably going to be required.
Mr. Murphy boarded Mr. Schwarzenegger's Gulfstream-4 jet at 8 a.m. on the day the article was published for the half-hour flight to San Diego, where the bus tour was to begin. He spoke with Mr. Schwarzenegger about how he should respond to the charges.
Mr. Schwarzenegger decided himself that a blanket apology was in order, aides said, and he issued it extemporaneously.
"Yes, it is true that I was on rowdy movie sets," the actor and former bodybuilder said. "And to those people that I have offended I want to say to them, I am deeply sorry about that and I apologize because this is not what I'm trying to do."
While he took a momentary dip in the polls over the weekend, Mr. Schwarzenegger remained calm and seemingly above it all as more women stepped forward to accuse him. At a rally in a town called Pleasanton, a radio talk show host encouraged the crowd to seek out a Los Angles Times reporter and beat him up. A group of heckling women were pelted with bottles and placards. At one stop, a woman obviously untroubled by the sexual misconduct charges yelled, "You can grope me, Arnold!"
But in the end the accusations mattered little and by Tuesday night, Mr. Schwarzenegger had accomplished what many thought impossible -- uniting the state's fractious Republican Party and returning the governor's office to its hands.
At the victory celebration men in tailored suits drank Scotch and smoked Cuban cigars in the Century Plaza hotel and laughed at the misfortune of Gray Davis.
One giddy Schwarzenegger aide said, "Only in California, can you take down a sitting governor and be home by 11:30." 
Meanwhile Mr. Schwarzenegger swaggered around the penthouse Tuesday night, surrounded by hangers-on. It was the sort of scene reserved for movie stars and a very few newly elected leaders.

HEADLINE: EBay Founder Raises Foundation Endowment to $300 Million 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Jeffrey S. Skoll, a founder of eBay, the online auction company that is one of the few still successful Internet icons, has raised the endowment of his foundation to $300 million from $117 million.
 Although he is Canadian, Mr. Skoll has fast become one of this country's most active young philanthropists. He has given $15 million to support "social entrepreneurs," people operating nonprofit business ventures whose aim is to help the needy help themselves and in doing so, help society at large. 
 "I've been sort of operating on the installment plan," Mr. Skoll, who is 38, said jokingly in an interview at the Hotel Chelsea in New York, where his new film production company was shooting a movie. "I've been incubating the foundation, and now it's ready to move to the next stage."
While foundation assets grew rapidly during the 1990's, the weak economy and seesawing stock market have chipped away at endowments for the last three years. "The proportional increase in the value of this foundation's assets at this time is really unusual," said Steven Lawrence, director of research at the Foundation Center.
Mr. Skoll's stake in eBay is valued at $3.6 billion, and he said he intended to keep expanding his philanthropy. The most recent infusion will allow the foundation to help underwrite the replication of successful programs. 
For instance, the Skoll Foundation has pledged $300,000 over two years to ApproTEC, a nonprofit business to help subsistence farmers in Africa become small businessmen with the help of simple technology. 
ApproTEC makes a variety of human-powered machines that help small farmers make their land more productive. One of its best-sellers is the Super Money Maker irrigation pump and its more plain-vanilla cousin, the Money Maker Plus, which operate somewhat like a Stairmaster and sell for $75 and $40, respectively.
"Using the Super Money Maker, a poor farmer can irrigate up to two acres of land in the dry season and cultivate high-profitability fruits and vegetables to generate cash," Martin Fisher, ApproTEC's executive director, said. "Without a pump, it's really only possible to irrigate about one-eighth of an acre with a bucket."
Mr. Fisher described Janet Ondiek, a widow with six children and two acres of land in western Kenya. She saved for a year to buy the Super Money Maker, made $3,200 in profit in the year after she bought it and employs two people, he said.
ApproTEC wants to replicate its success in Kenya and Tanzania in six other African countries over the next three years and create 100,000 businesses like Ms. Ondiek's. The Skoll Foundation's grant has allowed it to register as a tax-exempt organization in the United States and lease an office from which it can do its fund-raising, with the goal of pulling in the $28 million it needs to get to the next level.
"What I realized was that with these people and others like them," Mr. Skoll said, "just a little bit of money can go quite a long way and make quite a big difference." 
His foundation also works to create links between social entrepreneurs so that they can exchange ideas through an online system, and his movie company, Ovation Entertainment, is producing documentaries about them as a means of educating others about their activities.
"Their stories are often as dramatic and inspiring as any you would see at the movies, yet people were going to see Scooby-Doo and Spider-Man," Mr. Skoll said.

HEADLINE: No More Secretary Nice Guy 

 BODY:
President Bush has been famous for avoiding public squabbles among his top officials, mindful of the fratricidal wars of his father's White House and the Clinton administration. Until now. Suddenly, everyone seems mad at everyone else, even though the administration tried to calm things down yesterday. 
 Last week, the White House and the C.I.A. started pointing fingers over who had leaked an operative's name to a conservative columnist. Now Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld is upset with the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, and he has shared his annoyance with the world. The State Department is gloating about Mr. Rumsfeld's being chastised for botching postwar Iraq. And the White House is trying to spin the mess any way it can. 
 Mr. Rumsfeld's rebellion was touched off by David Sanger's report in The Times on Monday that the White House was reorganizing the control of postwar Iraq and Afghanistan under the wing of Ms. Rice. That did not sit well at the Pentagon. It saw the switch, correctly, as an attempt to suggest that the hawkish Mr. Rumsfeld was being edged aside in the face of criticism that Mr. Bush does not have an adequate plan for Iraq.
Pentagon officials say there is less here than meets the eye. But Mr. Rumsfeld took the trouble in an interview, with newspapers in Europe no less, to make his disdain for the White House power grab quite clear. Mr. Rumsfeld said he had known nothing of the reorganization until he read news accounts. He dismissed Ms. Rice's memo describing the move as a restatement of the obvious, which is that the National Security Council is supposed to "coordinate" (translation: not run) this sort of thing.
But White House officials say Mr. Rumsfeld did know about the change and bristled at his swipe at Ms. Rice. Well, Pentagon aides said in reply, Ms. Rice may have sent a memo. But she sends so many memos, how can a busy defense chief remember them all? Someone at the White House, they say, is lamely trying to mute criticism of postwar policy at Mr. Rumsfeld's expense. Secretary of State Colin Powell's team is delighted. While Mr. Rumsfeld has insisted on total control in Iraq, Mr. Powell's aides see the Rice memo as giving him more say.
As entertaining as all this is to fans of Washington psychodramas, there are important decisions to be made about postwar Iraq and not a lot of reassurance so far that they are being made correctly. If Ms. Rice's memo signals a real attempt to exercise political control over the violence and instability in Iraq, that would be welcome. But so far, the grandly named Iraq Stabilization Group seems more like an attempt to substitute title-building for nation-building -- reminiscent of this administration's announcement that it was dealing with unemployment by creating a new assistant secretary post at the Labor Department.

HEADLINE: Inventories Fall To a Low Point In Sales Terms 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Businesses unexpectedly reduced wholesale inventories in August to the lowest percentage of sales ever, selling from stockpiles to meet demand, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.
 The decrease of 0.2 percent in inventories, to a value of $288.6 billion, may set the stage for a pickup in economic growth and production this quarter as companies restock. 
 Sales by distributors rose 0.4 percent after gaining 0.5 percent in July, the report said. 
 "Inventories are very lean," said Richard Davidson, chief executive of Union Pacific, the biggest United States railroad company. "People are waiting until they see the whites of their eyes before they ship. For the last year or two, every quarter has not started out strong."
 Jonathan Basile, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston in New York, said inventory rebuilding was projected to contribute a percentage point to the economy's growth this quarter.
 Economists had forecast a 0.1 percent rise in August inventories after no change in July.
 Supplies of durable goods at wholesalers in August fell 0.5 percent, led by autos and auto parts, hardware, machinery and electrical supplies. Durable goods sales dropped 0.7 percent after rising 0.2 percent in July.
 Inventories of nondurable goods -- which include such things as drugs, groceries and petroleum -- increased 0.3 percent in August after gaining 1 percent the month before. A 4.5 percent jump in petroleum supplies led the increase. Sales of nondurables increased 1.5 percent.
 The inventory-to-sales ratio for August dropped to 1.2 months from the previous record low of 1.21 months set in July and March.
 Wholesalers account for about 25 percent of all business inventories. Retailers and factories make up the rest. The decline in the amount of unsold goods subtracted 0.74 percentage point from second-quarter economic growth of 3.3 percent. In the first quarter, when the economy expanded at a 1.4 percent rate, inventories subtracted 0.82 percentage point, Commerce Department figures showed last month.

HEADLINE: Shock Waves From a Political Earthquake 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I hope that this resounding victory by Arnold Schwarzenegger (front page, Oct. 8) will be the beginning of the end of the smear tactics of the Democratic Party and some of its constituencies. 
 I was nauseated by the depths to which the liberal media stooped to try to destroy Mr. Schwarzenegger in the last week of this election -- and this is what they did to a socially moderate Republican who is pro-choice and pro-gay rights! It backfired on them.

JOHN MORESCHI
Novato, Calif., Oct. 8, 2003

HEADLINE: THE CALIFORNIA RECALL: THE OVERVIEW; 
SCHWARZENEGGER LAYS FOUNDATION FOR A TRANSITION

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 

 BODY:
Arnold Schwarzenegger moved quickly Wednesday to prepare for governing, naming a prominent Republican congressman to run his transition and strongly suggesting that he would call on President Bush to provide federal aid to California, now in Republican hands.
 Mr. Schwarzenegger, who will become only the second governor in United States history to win office in a recall election, reached out to prominent Democrats and set a tone of confidence, good humor and reconciliation at his first news conference since his election. 
 "I made it very clear in my campaign that I will be the people's governor," Mr. Schwarzenegger said. "That is the most important thing: governor for the people, not for special interests, but for everybody." 
The movie-star governor-elect, whose celebrity helped drive his victory, said he would place his businesses in a blind trust and stop making films. Yet he still used movie terminology, telling reporters with relish that a final campaign appearance had been "a good visual." 
He largely avoided specifics about his plans for dealing with the state's biggest problems, including its chronic budget deficit.
But he repeated promises made during the campaign not to raise taxes, to repeal the recent tripling of vehicle registration fees and to rescind a law signed last month by Gov. Gray Davis that allows undocumented workers to apply for driver's licenses. 
Mr. Schwarzenegger's unusual rise to the state's highest office and his unconventional resume made his first 24 hours after the election a spectacle unlike any other for a newly elected governor.
He spoke on the telephone and took congratulations from national and international figures, including President Bush, Mr. Bush's father and Nelson Mandela. His news conference here attracted hundreds of journalists. 
Representative David Dreier, who along with former Gov. Pete Wilson was a chairman of the Schwarzenegger campaign, was named transition chief, with the task of assembling a staff of nearly 200 political appointees who would need to be in place before the end of next month.
Aware that he must work with Democrats, Mr. Schwarzenegger also conspicuously reached across the aisle to some of them, including Senator Dianne Feinstein, one of Mr. Davis's staunchest supporters.
Mr. Schwarzenegger's election in a state long controlled by Democrats gave the president an important beachhead for 2004. And Mr. Schwarzenegger made clear Wednesday that he expected his state to benefit from his relationship with Mr. Bush. He noted that California did not get its fair share of federal aid, and of the president, he said, "He promised me that he will do everything possible to help California, so I'm looking forward to working with him and asking him for a lot, a lot of favors." 
Mr. Schwarzenegger added that the two men might meet as early as next week, when Mr. Bush makes a fund-raising trip to California. 
Mr. Schwarzenegger expressed unbridled optimism that he would be able to work with the Democratic legislature.
"The legislators up there have gotten this message last night, that the people of California want change," he said.
And he touched all the right political bases, as evidenced by his phone call to Ms. Feinstein, the state's senior Democrat, who had to interrupt a news conference to take it.
"He is extraordinarily enthusiastic, as I think comes through, wants to get cracking, wants to do the job," she said.
Yet even as he was speaking, and as Ms. Feinstein and other top Democrats pledged their cooperation with his new administration, plans were afoot in Sacramento to call a special session of the Senate so that dozens of Democratic appointments to state boards and commissions could be confirmed before Mr. Schwarzenegger takes office.
And though Mr. Davis pledged a smooth transition, a spokesman said the governor was busily dealing with about 100 last-minute appointments as well as 279 bills from the recent legislative session.
Mr. Davis made no public appearances on Wednesday, and phones in his Sacramento office were switched to voice mail much of the afternoon as most of his nearly 200 staff members attended a session where they learned about unemployment benefits, retirement packages and other severance issues. 
The precise date of Mr. Schwarzenegger's inauguration is uncertain, but election officials expect it to be sometime before Thanksgiving, after the results have been certified.
"This quite possibly is the highest-profile gubernatorial election in American history," said Doug Stone, a spokesman for the secretary of state, the chief election officer. "There's going to be a desire by local elections officials to make sure that their reports are as complete and thorough as possible before they transmit it to us." 
Unofficial results show the recall of Mr. Davis passing by 55.4 percent of the vote to 44.6 percent. 
On the replacement ballot, Mr. Schwarzenegger finished first with 48.6 percent, or 3,744,132 votes. Lt. Gov. Cruz M. Bustamante, a Democrat, came in second with 31.6 percent, or 2,434,484 votes.
Two other measures on the ballot failed by wide margins. Proposition 53 would have set aside up to 3 percent of the state's general revenues for spending on infrastructure improvements, while Proposition 54 would have banned the state's collection of certain types of racial data.
Contrary to statements Mr. Schwarzenegger made during the campaign that he would spend only limited time in Sacramento, on Wednesday he indicated that he would essentially become a fixture in the state capital to help push through his legislative program.
While working out on his exercise equipment this morning, Mr. Schwarzenegger took a call from State Senator John Burton, one of California's most senior and influential Democrats. 
He also tended to family matters, assuaging the fears of his four children about his new life as an elected official, explaining to a son that it would be much like making a film.
"I promised him that I will see him as many times as possible," he said. "And it's like being on a movie set or on a movie location, that sometimes I'm home and sometimes I'm not home, so they understand, they're much calmer now about the whole thing."
Mr. Schwarzenegger instructed his transition team to begin work immediately and to set up headquarters in the state capital as soon as this weekend. 
The transition effort, unlike any in California history, will be performed at least at the beginning without the normal state appropriation -- which amounted to $650,000 during the 1998 transition from Mr. Wilson to Mr. Davis -- though Senator Burton said he was confident that the Legislature would make emergency financing available before too long.
Tensions around the handover of power, already heightened because of the partisan nature of the recall, were expected to be worse than usual because of the rare occurrence in California of a governor being forced from power by the electorate. 
It was the first time since Ronald Reagan defeated Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. in 1966 that a governor seeking to stay in office was dealing with a transition involving a new governor responsible for his ouster.
Mr. Schwarzenegger's campaign team has already begun to work behind the scenes on his biggest and most immediate task: he will be expected to have a budget proposal for next year prepared in just two months, and with an $8 billion shortfall carrying over from this year, he will be faced with an immediate list of draconian cuts.
The job will become even more difficult if Mr. Schwarzenegger fulfills one of his main campaign promises -- repealing the $4 billion increase in the state's vehicle tax. Mr. Schwarzenegger said at his news conference that one of his first acts as governor would be to invite independent auditors to review the state's books and help find areas to cut. He also hinted that the deficit might be much worse than expected, perhaps as large as $20 billion. 
"I want to open the books to the people of California, so that they can see the waste, where the billions of dollars are," he said.
But as a backdrop to all of it, Mr. Schwarzenegger must deal with continued ill feeling among hard-core Democrats, some of whom are considering a recall of their own. 
Ms. Feinstein said she would oppose such an effort, but she acknowledged that some Democrats were already poised to bankroll it.
"I think it should be held in abeyance," Ms. Feinstein said. "This is a very hard thing, and virtually every action in this arena brings on a reaction."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Does Drawing Still Matter? A Show That Suggests Some Answers

BYLINE:  By KEN JOHNSON 

 BODY:
There was a time when the idea of a visual artist who did not know how to draw would have been unimaginable. It was through drawing -- especially drawing nudes -- that artists learned how to fine-tune their visual perceptions and mirror truthfully with handmade marks the mercurial vagaries of psychological experience. It was the foundation that no career in painting or sculpture could be securely built without. 
 Countless artists still draw. It could be that we are in a golden age of drawing; "Drawing Now," a show last year at the Museum of Modern Art, barely hinted at the wealth and variety of what is out there. But drawing is not the foundation of many big careers these days. Conceptualists, performance artists, photographers, assemblagists and even many kinds of painters and sculptors do not need traditional drawing skills. They may produce plans, diagrams, collages, cartoons or rudimentary visual notes that will be marketed as drawing, but rarely anything like the kind of draftsmanship you associate with artists from Leonardo and Michelangelo to Ingres, Degas and de Kooning. 
 That the Drawing Center, an institution nominally dedicated to drawing, defines drawing not in terms of manual representational skills but according to support material -- i.e., anything made on paper qualifies -- is a reflection of this development. 
Does the marginalization of drawing matter? Absolutely, though only cranky conservatives seem to complain much about it.
If you are interested in pondering the question, a place to begin might be "A Fine Line: Drawings by National Academicians," a modest show of drawings at the National Academy of Design Museum by present and past members of the academy. The exhibition was organized by the Photo Realist painter Robert Cottingham.
It is not a great drawing show. All 33 works, most dating from the last two decades, are professionally competent, and some are impressive, but there is not a single unforgettable piece. Rather, the show functions best as a catalog of the varieties of line artists may put into play. In this sense it is an academic production, the kind of thing drawing instructors might take their beginning students to. 
The varieties of line are indeed diverse. They include the almost microscopically fine description of trees and a placid stream in ink by the Hudson River School painter Jasper Cropsey; all-over charcoal squiggles in an Impressionist-style landscape by Luise Kaish; scrawled, brightly colored pastel lines describing a masklike face by Irving Kriesberg; the delicate delineation of cliffs in Arizona by Kathleen Zimmerman; the jerky, primitivistic charcoal lines of a nude by Charles Cajori; the graceful, machinelike curves of a geometricized nude, made with repeated strokes of a light pencil by Philip Grausman; the pale, feathery hatching in a highly finished still life by William Bailey; the graphically definitive sketches of people, dogs and cakes from Wayne Thiebaud's notebooks; the sinuous, lifelike pencil lines in Mary Frank's sketches of giraffes or in Harvey Dinnerstein's small drawing of a nursing newborn; and much more. 
So within its own conservative terms -- those of the National Academy, that is -- there is pedagogical value here. It would be nice, by the way, to have a sequel to this show that would explore varieties of drawing by some of today's more adventurous artists. Still, the question of the larger importance of drawing remains. 
In an introductory essay posted on the wall, Mr. Cottingham talks in familiar terms about drawing, extolling its immediacy, intimacy and economy. More interestingly, he finds in drawing an unrivaled transparency: "Each line of a drawing," he observes, "besides contributing to the final image, stands as a unique record of the artist's thoughts at the exact moment that the line was brought into existence." At a time when more and more artists leave the execution of their works to machines, this legibility in drawing is worth remembering.
Something else, which Mr. Cottingham doesn't talk about, comes to mind. As you look around the exhibition, you will notice that each drawing, however true it may be to an individual's thinking, is also bound by a particular set of conventions: a style. Hudson River School, Impressionism, Cezanne, Cubism, Expressionism, Pop. Artists do not learn to draw only by recording pure, uncontaminated perceptions; they learns by also imitating other artists and then strive to make something distinctively individual out of the generic templates that they internalize.
A good drawing is more than just a feat of hand-eye or mind-body coordination. It's an exemplary struggle with society and culture: at best, a victory over forces that most of the time keep most of us from having the courage of our own originality.

"A Fine Line: Drawings by National Academicians" will remain at the National Academy of Design Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880, through Jan. 4.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Impressionist-style landscape: Luise Kaish's "Blossom Path" in "A Fine Line." (Photo by National Academy of Design Museum)
