HEADLINE: DataBank; 
An Extended Rally Depends on Earnings

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Stocks rallied last week and could continue to climb if corporate earnings reports for the third quarter meet expectations.
 A few companies, including PeopleSoft, announced last week that they beat third-quarter forecasts. 
The reporting gets into full swing this week, with announce-ments expected from Intel, Johnson & Johnson, Coca-Cola, Bank of America, and Merrill Lynch. Coke and Johnson & Johnson were down last week. Intel, Bank of America and Merrill Lynch were up. 
 Economic reports on inflation, consumer confidence and retail sales this week will be reviewed for further confirmation that the economic recovery is here to stay. While third-quarter growth is now forecast to be 5 percent to 6 percent, it is not clear if this pace can carry into next year.
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 102.37 points, or 1.1 percent, to 9,674.68; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 8.21 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,038.06. Both indexes touched their highest levels since June 2002 before slipping on Friday. The Nasdaq ended the week at its highest close since March 2002, rising 34.74 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,915.31. HEADLINE: Nepal Maoist Rebels Move Their Attacks Into Cities 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN

DATELINE: KATMANDU, Nepal 

 BODY:
In less than a month in this once tranquil capital, a police official cleaning his motorbike was shot at close range. Five bombs exploded with one, planted near a school, killing a 12-year-old boy. An army colonel was assassinated outside his home. 
 In each case, the police have blamed Maoist rebels, who have been waging an insurgency since 1996. In late August, they pulled out of peace talks and called off a seven-month cease-fire. In the weeks since, they have opened a new urban front in their campaign to replace the country's constitutional monarchy with a Communist republic. 
 Since the cease-fire ended, more than 400 Nepalis have died in the renewed fighting -- more than triple the number who died in the month before the cease-fire was imposed. Most of the deaths, as with those before the cease-fire, have been in the countryside, where 85 percent of Nepalis live. But now the urban elite are also watching their backs. 
 On Saturday, police officials in western Nepal said that at least 38 people, most of them Maoists, had been killed after the rebels attacked a police post on Friday. 
With the cease-fire broken, the brief run of optimism is over for this desperately poor Himalayan kingdom of 25 million people. Once again, newspapers are filled with daily reports of clashes and executions, displacement and terror, and attacks on rural infrastructure. 
The economy, already fragile, is sinking, as tourists and trekkers stay away. In fiscal year 2002, the economy shrank for the first time in two decades. 
This country was once known as a paradise, with gentle people and gorgeous terrain, including Mount Everest. But Nepal's patina of serenity always masked deep rural poverty, caste and ethnic discrimination and a concentration of wealth and power that many say has helped nourish the Maoist cause. The most recent World Bank statistics show 42 percent of the population below the poverty line.
That helps explain why the Maoists' ideology -- seen as bizarre and discredited just about everywhere else on the globe -- has gained a foothold here. The rebels, who first organized a political party, began their movement five years after the country instituted multiparty democracy, vowing to use Mao's strategies of guerrilla warfare to create a "classless and exploitationless society." 
The conflict, which has killed more than 7,500 people since 1996, promises to be even more brutal this time, in part as a result of American military aid to the government. Both the government and the rebels used the cease-fire to regroup and rearm, say diplomats, army officials and analysts here. 
The Maoists undertook a systematic campaign of extortion from businessmen, aid groups and villagers to fill their coffers. They corralled new recruits and infiltrated urban areas.
The number of soldiers in the Royal Nepal Army, formerly more of a show horse than an actual fighting force, has grown to 72,000 from 50,000 since November 2001, when an attack by the rebels drew the army into a battle that had at first been left to the police. Since then, the army has been heavily armed with the help of the United States, which is providing $17 million in military equipment and training, as well as India, which is deeply concerned about the conflict next door, and others.
The army's decades-old weapons have been replaced with mortars, machine guns and M-16 rifles, provided by the Americans, Indians and Belgians, as well as Indian and British helicopters. Counterinsurgency training has come from India and the United States.
Government statistics indicate that more than 60 percent of those killed in the seven-year conflict died in the year after the army entered the conflict and that most of them were labeled Maoists.
A report by Amnesty International last December estimated that half of those killings by the government might have been carried out without due process. As the last round of talks was getting under way in August, the army executed 18 rebels and 2 civilians near a remote village.
But in this mountainous country, military victory is impossible for either side, analysts say. 
The rebels, with an estimated 4,000 hard-core fighters, a militia of about 15,000 -- though the Maoists claim 100,000 -- and unsophisticated weaponry, can inflict terror in Katmandu, but would have a hard time taking it. They roam freely in the countryside and effectively control about 6 of 75 districts, but have never taken a district headquarters. 
An army spokesman, Col. Dipak Gurung, said the army could now penetrate almost anywhere the rebels operated, but he conceded that it could not hold those areas. "Our troops are stretched thinly all over the country," he said. By some estimates, nearly half the army is in Katmandu and the valley around it. 
Kamal Thapa, a government minister and a member of the negotiating team, said he thought the government could win -- but only by paying a "huge cost" in lives.
So each side tries to deliver enough blows to force the other back to negotiations. "I think they literally have to be bent back to the table," the American ambassador, Michael E. Malinowski, said of the rebels.
A year-old standoff also continues between King Gyanendra, who dismissed the Parliament last October, and the country's five major political parties, which have refused to join the government since then. Neither side shows any sign of compromise, although everyone agrees their disunity has worked to the Maoists' advantage. 
The talks with the rebels fell apart when the government refused to accede to the unconditional demand for an assembly to draft a new constitution. Diplomats, analysts and participants in the talks said there seemed to be differences among the Maoist leadership about the desirability of pursuing a military solution, and pressure to fight from cadres who had been fed an uncompromising ideological diet.
The Web site of the Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist) attributed the impasse to "the seemingly irreconcilable class and political contradiction between a feudal-bureaucratic monarchy backed by foreign imperialist powers and democratic forces fighting for sovereignty of the people."
Mr. Malinowski said human rights violations by the army could jeopardize aid to Nepal, but he has been more forceful in elucidating how abhorrent the United States government finds the Maoists' ideology and tactics. Last spring, the Maoists were added to the State Department's terrorist watch list, after they killed two Nepali guards at American facilities here.
Mr. Malinowski recently compared Baburam Bhattarai, the Maoists' chief ideologue, to Goebbels, Hitler's propaganda master. In a letter posted on the Internet recently, Mr. Bhattarai attacked Mr. Malinowski for what he called his McCarthyite "ideological disposition" and called America "one of the chief wreckers" of the peace talks.
Fearful of anti-American sentiment among the Maoists, aid groups are trying to play down their American connections. The United States Agency for International Development is trying to figure out how to deliver an additional $14 million of "insurgency relevant" American aid without revealing the American financing.

HEADLINE: In the Spotlight, Choreographer Energetically Takes On Dance 

BYLINE:  BY ROBERTA HERSHENSON

 BODY:
SHADOWS crossed a scrim in the middle of a 42nd Street dance studio as Peter Pucci considered the effect of six pairs of arms waving in the light. He crouched, jumped up, bit into an apple and sat on the floor, pondering - in his active fashion - the synchronized motions and their place in his choreography of "Harmony," a new musical that will begin previews on Nov. 25 in Philadelphia, and, if fortune smiles, could make it to Broadway. 
 The musical tells the true story of the Comedian Harmonists, a group of unemployed street musicians -three Jewish, three Gentile - who rose to fame in Germany in the 1920's and later clashed with the newly established Nazi party. Mr. Pucci called the group "one of the first boy bands," though it was hardly for teeny-boppers. The men sang in German, French and English, and mixed classical music into their popular entertainment brew. The most unexpected name connected with the show is Barry Manilow, who wrote the music; Barry Sussman wrote the book and lyrics. 
 "It's not typical Barry Manilow," said Mr. Pucci, 45, a nationally known dancer and choreographer. "People will be surprised by this music. Some is quite beautiful. Some is very funny. It's a big book musical with a lot of scene work."
He lives in Mount Kisco, where his group, Peter Pucci Plus Dancers, is also based. He is a versatile artist known for his work designing stage movements for directors like Sam Shepard, David Rabe and Joe Orton; for his choreography of new works for dance companies like the Joffrey Ballet, Colorado Ballet and Ballet Hispanico; and for his stage, film and television appearances as a longtime former member, principal dancer and co-choreographer of the group Pilobolus.
He was tapped for "Harmony" by David Warren, the show's director (also the director of the recent "Barbra's Wedding"), who first saw his work two years ago and hired him despite his lack of experience with big musicals. Mr. Warren said Mr. Pucci clinched the assignment by submitting ideas for "Harmony" that were "both highbrow and silly," perfect for a show about a singing group that was "musically sophisticated but profoundly witty."
The afternoon session with the scrim - which would be used in one number - was marked by playfulness, trial and error and inspiration, with Mr. Pucci ever mindful of the clock ticking down to the play's first rehearsals several weeks ahead. "There's a lot at stake, a lot of money involved," he said during a break. He noted that the Manilow-Sussman team had worked for 10 years to stage the show, which was presented in an earlier form in 1997 in California. Hence the careful hours spent matching movements to blocks of dialogue and song, and the actors serving as stand-ins for the show's principals. 
Dressed in blue running pants and a long-sleeved black shirt to ward off the chill of the studio's air-conditioning, Mr. Pucci -- known variously as Peter, Pete and Pooch -- looked like the athlete he was until the age of 19, when dance took over his life. Twenty-six years later, he is riding a crest of fulfilling personal work; besides the musical, he is working with the Katonah-based singer and songwriter Sloan Wainwright on a solo evening-length piece, "To Begin Again," that is based on his experiences in dance. Set to Ms. Wainwright's jazzy, bluesy takeoff on Chopin's "Nocturnes," the work will have its premiere at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan on Jan. 9. 
In addition, Mr. Pucci, along with artists like the poet Billy Collins, the painter James Rosenquist and the composer Alan Menken, will receive an arts award from the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts at its 25th anniversary gala on Oct. 18 at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College. The choreographer and singer-composer will perform a sneak preview of "To Begin Again" during the evening. 
Raised with five siblings by a single mother in a Baltimore public housing project, Mr. Pucci was a physical education major in college when he took his first dance course. Before that, the only live dancing he saw was his mother jitterbugging around the house. He was a Hall of Fame high school football player and an all-American relay racer. 
He described his awakening to dance in an autobiographical essay he uses in place of a conventional resume. "I was required to take a course in movement improvisation, a disguised dance class for jocks," he wrote. "That first improvisation class literally changed my life. I found a way to direct my energy in an intellectually rewarding manner." 
Soon he was enrolling in more dance classes, "often enduring the stares of my fellow phys ed majors as I showed up in the locker room dressed in tights." His final conversion to dance, at the end of his senior year, was like a mystical experience. "During an umpire class," he writes, "I looked up from the field and saw the dance department building where I was spending more and more of my time. Three weeks away from getting my degree, I quit phys ed and became a dance major." 
But he did not give up athletics entirely; he incorporated athletics into his art. Directors call upon him to design stage movements where an actor must throw a ball, swing a tennis racket or roll off a bed. In 1999 he choreographed the signature theater piece "Pucci: Sport," which explores how dance relates to sports in nine "innings": badminton, baseball, basketball, boxing, football, Frisbee, hockey, surfing and tennis. The work is a natural for introducing young people to dance, and Mr. Pucci presents it in schools and community centers. "We try to get kids interested in being physical," he said. "We're such an electronic society. The sports show is a way to get people into the theater and share a communal experience."
Sunlight stole into the studio through gaps in the lowered blinds as Mr. Pucci moved behind the scrim to demonstrate a hand motion, then darted back to view the shadow effect. 
Like a painter he was sketching the basic idea of the work, but was prepared to change the canvas as the need arose. Mr. Manilow's music for the show played in the background, and Mr. Pucci praised its "beautiful harmonies."
He moved behind the scrim again, laughing with the actor-dancers. Shadow play was the subject, but Mr. Pucci was enjoying the spotlight.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Pay $20 Million In Glen Cove Cleanup 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
FOR months, the mounds of excavated dirt laced with radioactive industrial waste and heavy metals have been ready to be shipped out of Glen Cove, piled along a bank of Glen Cove Creek. 
 The mounds, near a public esplanade the city formally opened last month, have been a stumbling block in the redevelopment of the city's waterfront. 
 Now, in a partial settlement that was heralded as a major breakthrough in a Superfund case, an infusion of $20 million in federal money will soon send the 60,000 cubic yards of contaminated material to a disposal site, probably in Utah.
The area in Glen Cove is known as the Li Tungsten Superfund site. The federal liability stems from its ownership of land and buildings there during and after World War II. Tungsten produced there was used in light-bulb filaments, drill bits, artillery shells, tanks and planes. 
As part of the settlement, the city, which has owned part of the site for about 25 years, agreed to pay $1.6 million for the cleanup, in addition to the $3.4 million it had paid previously. The Wah Chang Smelting and Refining Company, the plant operator during some of the period contaminated waste was disposed of along the creek, agreed to pay $700,000. 
The federal Justice Department and the Environmental Protection Agency announced the settlement on Sept. 30, after a year of negotiations. It has been 11 years since the area was listed as a Superfund site and 9 years since the cleanup began. 
Three federal agencies -- the Defense Department, the Commerce Department and the General Services Administration -- will share the $20 million payment and agreed to pay an estimated $7.5 million toward future cleanup costs. With the total of new money approaching $30 million, officials said that one of the most seriously polluted sites on Long Island was nearer to becoming a brownfields success story. 
"It's the best thing to happen in Glen Cove in 20 years," said Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau county executive. Mr. Suozzi proposed the waterfront revitalization plan in the mid-1990's, when he was Glen Cove's mayor. 
E.P.A. officials estimated last week that final cleanup costs would be about $50 million but emphasized that the cost could go even higher. Jane M. Kenny, the E.P.A regional administrator, said the settlement would reimburse the agency for the $20 million it had already spent on the cleanup.
Ms. Kenny said the agency would continue to try to recover money from some 20 small and large companies liable for cleanup costs and wanted them to share in shipping out the contaminated mounds.
"We are still expecting the responsible parties to remove that soil, and we have ordered them to do so," she said. 
Deborah Zwany of the United States attorney's office in Brooklyn, said, "We will continue to pursue the other potentially responsible parties." . But, she added, "we wanted to move forward with the cleanup -- that was the most significant thing for us."
Companies named in the E.P.A. order range from General Electric and Teledyne to small metallurgy concerns. Nassau County is also named, but Mr. Suozzi said the county's liability was minor.
The E.P.A. is still studying contamination in Glen Cove Creek but hoped to announce a proposal this winter, Ms. Kenny said. The Army Corps of Engineers halted a dredging project in the creek two years ago after it found unexpectedly high levels of radium and thorium, radioactive elements associated with tungsten ore.
The Superfund site comprises 26 acres where the Li Tungsten plant once operated, and Captains Cove, a property of nearly equal size about half a mile to the west on Hempstead Harbor. Operators of the tungsten plant once dumped contaminated material there, and this is where the the mounds of contaminated soil are piled. 
Glen Cove's mayor, Mary Ann Holzkamp, said the settlement would enable the city and a private developer, the Glen Isle Development Company, to make final plans for a major project at the Superfund site. An agreement, announced in February, will allow the developer to buy the land, at a price tentatively set at $20.5 million, and to build retail space, a hotel and as many as 350 housing units. 
Jed Morey, the Republican candidate for Glen Cove mayor in next month's election, questioned the $1.6 million the city agreed to in the federal settlement. "Our city's attorneys could have fought harder on that aspect," said Mr. Morey, the publisher of The Long Island Press, a weekly newspaper. "We continue to do things to move this waterfront project forward, and we don't fight hard enough for our own piece."
Mayor Holzkamp, a Democrat seeking re-election, said the settlement was fair. "Mr. Morey has no idea of the magnitude of this settlement and of the work that went into it," she said.
Others said they would just be grateful to see the last of the contaminated soil. "We have been waiting a very long time to get this material out of here," said Peter Rapelje, a co-chairmanof the Li Tungsten Community Task Force, which advised on the cleanup. "This is a very good thing."

HEADLINE: Hovering Near Hopelessness 

BYLINE:  By JEREMY PEARCE

DATELINE: MILLBURN 

 BODY:
ON an early autumn morning, commuters at the train station in this town's picturesque Short Hills section stand as crisply as they always have, immersed in their newspapers, but it is no longer business as usual.
 The violent deaths of a father and his 7-year-old son last month -- under investigation as a probable murder-suicide -- have unsettled parents and schoolchildren, disturbed the suburban calm at its roots and follow yet another unexplained tragedy. 
 Only six days earlier, while children fished in Millburn's Taylor Park, a 71-year-old sometime resident shot himself to death on a park bench, beginning a series of public and agonizing events that has led to days of questions without answer. Deepening the wound, said the local police, neither suicide appears to have left a note to unravel the mystery of the township's deadliest month in memory.
 "We continually ask the question, 'Why?"' said Mayor Thomas C. McDermott. "There is still just lots of speculation -- of what we've heard, what we've read and of what we've seen." 
 According to the police, on the afternoon of Sept. 29, an unemployed banker, Richard Alexander Josephs, 53, walked onto the tracks at the Short Hills station shortly before a New Jersey Transit train was to arrive. He was struck and killed instantly. The Millburn police, calling later at Mr. Josephs's home in Short Hills, a short distance down the tracks from the station, discovered the body of his son, Eric Cameron Josephs, who had just begun the second grade at the Hartshorn School. The child's body was "found face up in his bed in his pajamas," according to an account from the Essex County prosecutor's office, which has taken over the case.
 Many presume that Mr. Josephs's 35 months of unemployment contributed to financial pressures and fed a despondency more common in upper-crust suburbia than might be suspected.
 Mr. McDermott said that all three deaths had jolted the town, although the loss of Eric Josephs seemed to cut deepest -- Millburn has not experienced a murder in at least a decade and never had a victim that was a child. 
 "I don't know how you tell children about this, but I think you tell them the truth," said the mayor, who also has a daughter in the second grade at the school. "That's my gut feeling as a parent."
 Although Essex County investigators, awaiting results from the autopsies, declined to discuss Mr. Josephs's possible motivations, some psychologists have said the three-year economic recession and hopelessness among those out of work could be cause enough to begin a mental depression. 
 Indeed, although New Jersey's labor figures recently brightened somewhat, about 260,100 workers in the state remain without jobs while unemployment hovers at 5.9percent, in a period termed confusingly by economists as a "jobless recovery."
 In reviewing what is known about the Josephs case, Dr. Maurice Elias, a professor of psychology at Rutgers, said it was possible that despair over the family's financial distress may have begun a shift in outlook that ended in a child's death.
 Last week, the Star-Ledger reported on lawsuits by a bank and a credit card company against Mr. Josephs that sought to collect $60,000 in debts, as well as bank foreclosure proceedings on the family's house on Hobart Gap Road, which had $265,000 outstanding on its mortgage. Mr. Josephs, a graduate of Fordham and New York University, was last employed in November 2000, when he departed the Bank of Nova Scotia as a managing director.

'A Logic' to Many Suicides
 Dr. Elias emphasized there could be "a logic" to many suicides often not readily apparent. "He may have thought he was saving the child from a fate far worse than we can imagine," he speculated.
 He paused, then continued: "You could almost think of this tragedy as a double homicide. Mr. Josephs put himself in a position to be killed -- in one sense, he really didn't kill himself. He chose a method that, in essence, was not by his own hand. He may have seen his son being sucked into a black hole that he would consider a fate even worse than death."
 A second psychologist, Dr. Janet Sigal of Fairleigh Dickinson University, offered an alternative explanation. She said that Mr. Josephs's suicide could also be interpreted as "a hostile act against the spouse."
 "If nothing else," said Dr. Sigal, who studies domestic violence, "these deaths would produce guilt in his wife. They guarantee that the wife is going to be brought under public scrutiny and involved in a very public investigation. The issue for the police is to determine if this was a dysfunctional family."
 Further, Dr. Sigal recommended the completion of what she called a "psychological autopsy" --interviews with family members, friends and former employers -- before making a firmer diagnosis.
 Joseph Delmar, a spokesman for the state Division of Youth and Family Services, which monitors child abuse, said there was no record of abuse in the Josephs home, and that the agency keeps no official count of murder-suicides involving parents and children. But Mr. Delmar added he believed that the phenomenon had occurred "three or four times" in New Jersey in the past five years. 
 In fact, in July, a Camden County man, Steven Lee Wasserman, 44, killed a former girlfriend and possibly his 10-year-old daughter before poisoning himself and his 8-year-old son with carbon monoxide gas. Dr. Elias said he would not necessarily expect such cases to be preceded by instances of beatings or other obvious warning signs.
 Indeed, another psychologist, Dr. Anthony D'Urso of Hackensack University Medical Center's Audrey Hepburn Children's House, said he would anticipate quite the opposite. 
 "You're not going to see a longstanding pattern of sadistic behavior from the parent," Dr. D'Urso said. "In fact, you're more likely to see overinvolvement on the parent's part or overprotection of the child."
 Dr. D'Urso dismissed the notion that a child's murder would be a stroke of revenge, and described Mr. Josephs's state as probably being one of "desperation and helplessness." As chairman of the New Jersey Child Fatality and Near Fatality Review Board, whose members are appointed by the governor, Dr. D'Urso has studied more than 100 of child deaths over the past four years.
 "I don't want to oversimplify this," headded. "These parents see the suicide as a relief to their conflict. It's not clear thinking, but a fairly advanced state of depression. After a time, it becomes mental illness."
 The larger factors that affected Mr. Josephs, a former commuter, are less in question. Despite a mild improvement registered in New Jersey's unemployment rate, joblessness in New York State and its global banking center in Manhattan stood last month at 8 percent. Dr. Joseph J. Seneca, an economist and chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisers, said the state lost 42,800 jobs from 2000 to 2002, in a downward trend that reversed itself only recently.
 This year, the state's economy, leavened by a rebounding stock market, has created about 20,500 new jobs -- a figure still well below an annual average gain of 50,000 jobs expected in the longer term.

Fewer Jobs Being Created
 "There has been quite a falling off in job creation from the boom years of the late 1990's," said Dr. Seneca, who added that the situation in Manhattan had been worsened by the attacks on World Trade Center and the subsequent movement of some companies and financial institutions to locations outside of the city. "But New Jersey's economy has fared relatively well, compared to what we're seeing nationally."
 Dr. Eileen Kaplan, director of Montclair State University's M.B.A. program, noted the broader economic uncertainty that threatened mainly blue-collar jobs in recent years has finally reached the white-collar class. 
 Dr, Kaplan mentioned the practice of "offshoring" -- the export by corporations of jobs in accounting, technology and financial services to foreign countries -- and said she sensed that it began to diminish business recruiting on campuses in the past year.
 "There's a pervasive anxiety among our students," said Dr. Kaplan, who is a psychologist. "They're watching white-collar jobs move to India and China. They understand that what costs $12,000 to employ an individual abroad could cost $70,000 here, in salary and benefits."
 In grasping for other stresses on Mr. Josephs, Mayor McDermott emphasized the pressures that can go along with maintaining a Short Hills zip code. The Josephs's three-story home was assessed at $586,200, a value well above the state average, but modest in comparison to the surplus of grander residences listed for sale in Short Hills last week, which ranged in price from $2 million to more than $4 million. Moreover, the average local tax bill in Old Short Hills last year topped $21,000.
 "A lot of people here are under financial pressure," explained Mr. McDermott. "A lot of people are right now living on credit. In a town like ours, we make sacrifices to make the best for our families."
 Lynne Ranieri, a vice president of the Millburn Historical Society, said there was a "perception of a difference" in the cultures of the Short Hills section and the larger township of Millburn, where housing prices tend to be lower.
 "In the 19th century, Short Hills was developed as an 'ideal community' by Stewart Hartshorn, inventor of the roller window shade, in order to encourage commuters to come here," said Ms. Ranieri, who lives in Short Hills. "A lot of the early residents of Millburn were mill workers. The nature of the origins of the two would cast each in a different light."
 But, she cautioned, "I feel that today that we're all one community." In recent years, to a large degree the social and economic distinctions have blurred. 
 In recording Mr. Josephs's death, New Jersey Transit said that he was the 16th person to die on the rails this year. Six of those victims have been confirmed as suicides; the remaining 10, including Mr. Josephs, remain officially under investigation. It was the first such death at the Short Hills station this year. The total number of deaths this year is down somewhat from last year, when 27 people were killed along the tracks, 18 of them judged to be suicides. In both years, the proportion of males dying to females was about the same, at 2 male deaths for every one female.
 Ken Hitchner, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit, said the authority issues track safety messages, but they are generally intended for school audiences and not adult commuters. Part of the reason is the unpredictability of suicides -- stations in Egg Harbor, Asbury Park and Redbank this year have each been the site of two track deaths, but the system contains 187 other train stations.

Second Suicide in Days
 "It's a charged issue," said Mr. Hitchner. "How do you reach a suicide? Suicide is never really directly addressed."
 Millburn's first suicide occurred on Sept. 23 in Taylor Park. Police Captain David Barber said that Robert McAuliffe, 71, a former Springfield resident and a temporary resident of the township, shot himself in the head with a small-caliber handgun. As with Mr. Josephs, Mr. McAuliffe apparently did not write a note, leaving the police unsure about his motive. The shooting took place at about 4:30 in the afternoon, while children and pedestrians strolled through the park. Mr. McAuliffe survived for a short time before being pronounced dead at Overlook Hospital in Summit.
 Offering another insight, Dr. D'Urso, the child psychologist, said the apparent murder of Eric Josephs had brought out a frustration he frequently felt in cases of other child fatalities.
 "We always look to the government, to the authorities to protect kids," he said. "But cases like this one signal that it is the role of citizens to protect children. The state couldn't help with this one."

HEADLINE: Networking Has Run Dry, Long-Term Unemployed Say 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER S. STEWART

 BODY:
NEARLY three years into the worst employment slump since World War II, many unemployed professionals are finding that the job networks they have been tapping are no longer producing. 
 This turn of events -- which some call network burnout or network fatigue -- appears to be a natural consequence of too many job seekers asking for too many favors. And many people in a position to hire are getting tired of it. 
 "It's a lot like spam," said Diane DiResta, president of DiResta Communications, which assists in career development. "People keep hitting up the same contacts over and over again. But people have a lot more to do these days and are less benevolent than they were in the past. There's no time for all the requests." 
Networking has been a highly effective way for many professionals to land a job, and that makes desperate job seekers that much more determined to hit up any and all contacts. According to a recent survey conducted by Bernard Haldane, the national career management firm, 61 percent of responders found their last job through networking while only 3 percent landed a job through the Internet and 16 percent by newspaper listings. Another outplacement company, Lee Hecht Harrison, put the networking number around 80 percent.
When Wayne Boatwright lost his job with Accenture, the global management consulting firm, he expected that his expansive web of friends and acquaintances would continue to help him in his search for new employment until he succeeded. 
But after two years of searching, this assistance came to an end. "I found that people aren't as likely to respond after a while of looking," said Mr. Boatwright, a 41-year-old lawyer. "You can only go back to the well so many times. You ask them once or twice for a referral or a favor. But when you go three or four times, people start to get a little tired of helping. It gets uncomfortable."
Mr. Boatwright said that even friends started to avoid his phone calls and e-mail messages. "Instead of saying something to me, a couple of them would mention to my wife that I'd contacted them again. They might tell her, 'I thought Wayne was working on the last contact I gave him four months ago."'
Many experts are baffled as to what might work for job seekers whose networks are drying up. "Sad thing to confirm, but networking has hit burnout," said Stephanie Pinson, president of the executive search firm Gilbert Tweed, in New York. "I'm not sure the best way to go about it anymore. That's why so many people are dropping out of the job market. They don't know who else to talk to, or are just getting tired of not hearing anything. It's a very different market now."
According to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, 265,000 adults stopped looking for work in August, the highest monthly total since March 2001. The total number of workers who have stopped searching has ballooned to more than half a million, the highest number of discouraged workers in nine years.
Sam Reese, president of Miller Heiman, a sales consulting company in Reno, Nev., said he had four or five people that call him frequently about work. "They're driving me nuts," Mr. Reese said. "One of them calls me weekly. I get the same voice mail every Thursday saying, 'Sam, I got another opportunity and I want to run it by you in case you have something better for me.'
"Then he calls my assistant panicking and saying that he's got to talk about this situation before he agrees to take the other job. So I call him back and say, 'For God's sake take it, take it will you?' Of course, he doesn't have any offer at all. He's just calling me to check in."
Susan Long, who lost her sales job a year ago at Furnitureland South, an international furniture company in Greensboro, N.C., says she thinks she is on a handful of people's to-do lists. And she is convinced that those lists have been forgotten or lost in a mess of papers. 
"I'm sure they're just busy now and can't deal with me," said Ms. Long, who is 46. "I used to call them and they'd get back to me. Not anymore. I feel like the silent majority saying that networks don't work. It's like there's an elephant in the living room and no one is talking about it." 
Craig Coleman has seen the same phenomenon up close. Since he was laid off four years ago as director of forecasting for the hosiery manufacturer Kaiser-Roth, he has watched his network shrink drastically. "After a while, people drop you off the list," said Mr. Coleman, 54. "I used to go out to lunch with people. But after you've been out of work for a while you can't really reciprocate much. You're not fun and people feel sorry for you. In the past, people would call back. But hardly anyone does anymore."
Still, some employers continue to rely on networks. John Lederer, vice president for sales at Popkin Software, which is based in New York, says that 7 out of his last 10 hiring decisions were based on information from people he knew. "I put a lot of stock in referrals," he said.
John Challenger, president of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, an outplacement firm in New York, said: "It's a lot like asking everyone you know to borrow money. And no one likes doing that. But the silver lining is that the more you network, the sooner it's over and the less burnout you go through."
Some intrepid job seekers are developing entirely new networks in place of contacts that are no longer helpful. For Mr. Boatwright, that has meant attending local job support groups held at churches and community centers and participating in networking sites on the Internet like Ryze.com. 
Mr. Boatwright is also taking a new tack with his existing network. He and his wife are expecting a baby, and he has written a letter to his friends saying that if he does not land a job soon he and his family will have to move out of town.
"It lit the fire under them," he said. "I think they appreciate the change in circumstances. It's not easy to say 'Hey, I need some help.' It's just as hard for them. But this changes it up enough that it will probably make a difference."

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: TRIBAL STRIFE; 
British Mediate Hatfields and McCoys, Iraqi-Style

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON

DATELINE: BASRA, Iraq, Oct. 11 

 BODY:
The Bukhatra tribe and the Bukheet tribe are feuding again. Capt. Tai Saukuru of the British Army is stuck in the middle, again.
 To an outsider, the tribes seem as similar as their names. Their houses are jumbles of cinder block, their streets trash-strewn alleys, their children barefoot, their men unemployed, their women an afterthought. Since June, when a Bukhatra man shot the nephew of the Bukheet tribal leader, they have been busy killing each other. 
 In August, Captain Saukuru orchestrated a cease-fire. It collapsed on Monday, and three killings quickly followed. Sidestepping the local police, Captain Saukuru on Tuesday asked the senior Shiite Muslim cleric in Basra to intervene. The following night, the captain found himself in a mosque with a roomful of belligerent tribesmen. 
By luck and design, the 12,000 British soldiers occupying southern Iraq have had an easier time than the 120,000 American troops in the rest of the country.
After decades subduing strife in Northern Ireland, the British Army here prides itself on soothing local sensibilities. This summer, British soldiers avoided the neighborhood sweeps that stirred trouble for American troops. And the rules controlling when British troops can shoot at Iraqis are stricter than those of the United States military.
At the same time, the Shiite Muslims who dominate southern Iraq suffered particularly under the rule of Saddam Hussein, and they are more tolerant of the occupation than the Sunni-dominated area around Baghdad that the United States controls. No British soldiers have been killed here since late August, while nearly 30 American troops have died from hostile fire in the same period.
So the British reacted gingerly when the feud began this summer. 
"There is no space for arrogance in this country, because arrogance can cost you your life," said Captain Saukuru, a 27-year-old native of Fiji who left the Fijian Army for the British army two years ago, after marrying a British woman. Captain Saukuru has an easy rapport with the tribes, who at first mistook him for a Kuwaiti or Saudi, but he acknowledges that the culture of blood feuds baffles him.
"You've got to have an approach, a personality, a sense of humor to deal with this lot," he said.
But the British experience shows that even the best-intentioned of outsiders cannot always solve complex clan battles. And the British effort to respect local sensibilities may carry long-run dangers of its own. In trying to work out a new truce with the help of Imam Ali Abdul Hakim, Captain Saukuru went outside the Iraqi civil justice system. That implicitly encouraged the tribes to rely on Islamic law and undercut the Iraqi police, who are struggling to gain respect.
Noah Feldman, an assistant professor at New York University who is advising Iraqi leaders, said, "It's always better to use the courts to build up your legitimacy."
Still, the current weakness of the Iraqi courts and the strength of tribal bonds here may have left the British little choice, Mr. Feldman said in a telephone interview from Washington. "Alternative dispute resolution outside the courts is sometimes the best way to achieve peace, especially in cultures where group identity matters a lot," he said. 
Captain Saukuru, who arrived in Iraq in June for a six-month stint with the First Battalion of The King's Regiment, said Wednesday that he did not regret turning to Imam Hakim for help. "Realistically, we're in an Islamic community, and Islamic rules are the paramount rules," he said. "At the end of the day, Islamic law still stands." 
The British first became involved in the feud after firefights erupted between the tribes in July. Three people were killed, one of whom was shot by British troops. To stop further violence, Captain Saukuru asked Imam Hakim to settle the dispute. The imam ordered 18 Bukheet families, with about 400 people, to leave the crowded slum that the tribes share here in Basra, the largest city in southern Iraq. That move eased tensions. But many of the evicted families have returned, and the truce collapsed Monday when a Bukhatra killed a Bukheet man who had come back. Two more killings followed, bringing the death toll from the feud to seven. Both tribes, however, put the toll at six, not counting the death of a woman.
So Captain Saukuru appealed again to Imam Hakim, a gentle-looking man with a brown robe and a bushy beard. After turning the captain down -- "He said, 'I've had enough of the two tribes,' " Captain Saukuru said -- Imam Hakim relented and said he would look for a compromise.
But compromise was hard to find at the mosque, where the two tribes faced each other across a narrow room as brass samovars of tea brewed on an electric stove and Imam Hakim sat at the front beside Ciaran Griffin, a British lieutenant colonel. After a few minutes, the meeting slipped into disorder, with tribesmen shouting at one another and the imam. As turmoil mounted, Imam Hakim lost his patience and walked out, ordering three leaders from each side into his private study.
Inside the imam's office, Sheik Nasir Ramadhan of the Bukhatra and Sheik Jassim Jaber of the Bukheet made their cases to Imam Hakim as the British officers watched. The tribes disagree about nearly every fact related to the dispute, including the tribal affiliation of the most recent victim, an issue that has further complicated the feud.
Sheik Jaber of the Bukheet told Imam Hakim that the newest victim, who lived in the town of Zubayr, was not a member of his tribe. The sheik insisted that the Bukhatra negotiate separately with a third tribe to resolve that killing.
Sheik Ramadhan insisted that the dead man, Saalem Ajr Mazbun, was a legitimate target and distantly related to the Bukheet. The killing should be considered a part of the feud, Sheik Ramadhan said.
After two hours of back-and-forth, Imam Hakim essentially issued a stay, ordering a five-day truce. Then he left town, traveling to Najaf, the religious center.
Imam Hakim's work had finished, at least for the moment, but Captain Saukuru's had only begun. On Thursday afternoon, the captain headed to visit the sheiks for hours of consultations and endless glasses of tea.
In a white room, a portrait of the Shiite martyr Ali in the corner, Sheik Jaber complained that the Bukhatra had set off the newest round of violence. Nearby, in a smaller and dirtier room with a similar picture of Ali, Sheik Ramadhan worried that the brother of the Zubayr man his tribe had killed would take revenge. "He's looking for al Bukhatra, driving around," the sheik said.
The captain promised to try to persuade the third tribe not to open a new cycle of killings. Meanwhile, he urged both sides to respect the truce. 
"We want a complete solution," he told Sheik Ramadhan. But the sheik did not seem to be convinced that that was likely. 
Asked what happened on Monday, he laughed and said, "We killed one from al Bukheet, and they killed one from us, and then of course we killed one," the sheik said, as lightly as an auctioneer calling off bids.
By day's end, Captain Saukuru was no closer to gaining a permanent truce than he had been in the morning. And with the cease-fire set to expire on Monday, both tribes appeared to be spoiling for a fight.
"I'm not ready for one battle," said Sheik Jaber. "I'm ready for 10."
On Saturday, with the tribes no closer to agreement, Captain Saukuru said he might have to give up on his effort to use Imam Hakim to settle the feud. Instead, he plans to demand that both tribes hand over suspects to him or the Iraqi police.
"The only way forward is to arrest the killers," he said.
If the tribes do not cooperate, the British Army is prepared to make the arrests, Captain Saukuru said.
"If that means having soldiers in the village to look out for them, then we'll do it," he said "We've more or less exhausted the tribal side of things."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Sheik Jassim Jabr, left above, of Al Bukheet, an Iraqi tribe in Basra, visited Khalif Kadhem, a tribe member who was paralyzed after being shot in July by members of a rival tribe, Al Bukhatra. Capt. Tai Saukuru of the British Army, below, met with Bukhatra tribesmen in an effort to settle the feud. (Photographs by Samantha Appleton/Aurora, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: After the Storm, Shattered Crab Shacks and Lives 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: TANGIER ISLAND, Va. 

 BODY:
The Chesapeake Bay was smooth as varnished maple as Mitchell Shores steered his skiff toward Tangier Sound. Crab huts on stilts stood like egrets in the shallow inlet. Watermen braided nets and tinkered with engines. The scene seemed postcard perfect. 
 But the bay that gives the watermen so much had also taken something away. 
 Several huts were bowled over like dollhouses before a rampaging child. Electric poles tilted at odd angles. A boat was sunk in the muck. And there was a pile of splintered planks and crumpled wire-mesh traps: the remains of Mr. Shores's crab house, a victim of Hurricane Isabel.
Mr. Shores, a grizzled 66-year-old in a faded red flannel shirt who has been crabbing since he was a teenager, squinted against the sun and clucked his tongue as he surveyed the wreckage.
"Terrible, ain't it?" he said, pulling at his bushy mustache. "In one day, to wipe out all you done all your life."
For more than three centuries, Tangier Islanders have endured war, storms and creeping environmental hazards. They have seen their island overrun by raging tides. But old-timers say nothing since the nameless storm of 1933, and possibly earlier, has hit Tangier as hard as Hurricane Isabel did last month.
The storm's 80-mile-per-hour winds and 20-foot seas damaged or destroyed more than a dozen crab houses on the island's exposed eastern flank. The watermen lost their crab traps, dredging nets and coolers -- and with them their livelihoods. 
Most will recover, as they have before. But it will not be easy, because few have insurance, and those without it must wait for the federal government to help with grants or loans to cover damages that can run $20,000 and more per waterman. 
"It was just a disaster for the watermen," said the town's mayor, Edward Parks, a part-time waterman who lost much of his gear."Some of them will have to start all over."
Living off the water is about all they know on this marshy 3.5-mile-long island populated by 640 residents. This is not a summer getaway for the wealthy. Many here are descendants of families that settled here in the 17th century. Like the generations before them, they measure their fortunes by the bushel of oysters, clams and, most important, blue crabs.
Located 14 miles from Virginia's eastern shore, Tangier is reachable only by boat or airplane. Cars are for the most part not permitted on the island's narrow paths, and residents travel by bike or golf cart. There are seven restaurants, two churches, two grocery stores and one police officer. A doctor from the mainland visits on Tuesdays.
Islanders have their own dialect, which has been described as Elizabethan but can sound like a collision between South Boston brogue and North Carolina twang.
Many residents cherish their isolation and the sense of sanctuary it provides. They like the one-big-family feel of their town, the absence of crime, the knowledge that neighbors will look after their children. The only traffic jams occur when two people in their carts stop to talk. The major crime is speeding: 15 m.p.h. is the limit.
But for a few, Hurricane Isabel has shaken their assumptions. 
Marty Crockett, 36, was born and raised on the island, a scion of Tangier's original settlers. But the hurricane destroyed most of his crabbing equipment and part of his crab house. Three feet of water poured into the stately white Victorian house Mr. Crockett's family has owned for generations. 
He is considering what once seemed unthinkable: giving up the independence of crabbing to work the predictable hours and wages of a tugboat. He is even thinking of moving off the island.
"I love this place to death," Mr. Crockett said. "But in the water business, you never know whether they'll let you work, how much you'll make or if a storm will knock you out."
"With one breath of wind," he said, "you're out of business. Something you worked for all your life."
Some watermen weathered the storm just fine, finding that it stirred crabs from their hiding places, making catches more bountiful. But for others, it was the latest hardship in a difficult year. 
Deep cold last winter froze the inlet, making it impossible for some watermen to move their boats for weeks. A cool, rainy summer drove crabs into deeper waters, reducing catches.
And then Hurricane Isabel struck, abruptly ending what should have been the most profitable season of the year: the dredging of "peelers," crabs about to shed their shells. Each soft-shell crab can sell for $3 or more, 10 times as much as a hard-shell crab. 
Possibly the trend most damaging to Tangier's fragile way of life has been a steady exodus of its young people. A century ago, the island had more than 1,200 residents, sustained by seafood processing plants, a vigorous shipping industry and a bay full of crabs, clams and oysters. But with the declining fortunes of the seafood industry, few teenagers stay beyond high school. 
Four of the six seniors at the island's 97-student school said they planned to leave after graduating. Tugboat work, the military and college beckon more brightly than Tangier. 
"My dad used to push me to work on the water," said Brian Pruitt, 17. "But the years went by and he changed his mind. He said, 'If you've got any sense, go away.' "
Many watermen also say state regulations freezing the number of licenses for watermen have made it difficult for their children to get into the business. Without a license, a person can work as a mate on a boat but cannot start a business.
Daniel Mariano, 27, said he could barely support his wife and son on a mate's salary. Mr. Mariano has applied for crabbing licenses, but none have been available. The storm has made matters worse by wrecking his boss's business, leaving him temporarily unemployed.
"I work week to week," he said. "When I'm out of work a couple of weeks, it's hard to bounce back."
The freeze on licenses was instituted in the late 1990's to protect the dwindling crab population. But now many environmental groups support exempting Tangier Island from the restrictions to help preserve its way of life. 
"It's not like people here have a McDonald's where they can go to flip burgers," said Lonnie Moore, a former Tangier waterman who now works for the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, a nonprofit group. "It's either crabbing or leave."
But for many older residents like Mitchell Shores, there is nothing but crabbing. With no pension, 401(k) plan or significant savings, he keeps working.
Mr. Shores snickers at suggestions that hoisting crab traps, dredging for peelers and navigating the bay 16 hours a day, even in winter, are somehow enjoyable. It is not fun, he says; it is all he knows.
"In the water business," he said, "you don't retire."

(Photo by Associated Press); Mitchell Shores, a crabber for half a century, lost his crab house to the hurricane. "Terrible, ain't it?" he said. "In one day, to wipe out all you done all your life." HEADLINE: STATES AND CITIES RISK BIGGER LOSSES TO FUND PENSIONS 

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

 BODY:
Many state and local governments, facing ballooning pension promises to police officers, firefighters, teachers and other public employees, are rushing to sell bonds to cover the shortfall. That strategy has sometimes backfired in recent years, leaving taxpayers on the hook for even more debt.
 States and municipalities are drawn to bond sales because they bring instant cash, easing budget pressures without further tax increases or reductions in retirement benefits. 
 But critics say the bonds could prove costly for some officials using them -- and for the local taxpayers. The cities and states have to pay a fixed rate of interest on the bonds, and are essentially betting they can earn a higher rate of return by investing the proceeds in their pension funds. 
But recent investment losses have already left some cities and states on the hook for a mounting debt, covering not just the retirement money for their workers but also the interest on the bonds. New Orleans, Pittsburgh and New Jersey have all placed losing bets in recent years.
Almost all pension funds have suffered sizable losses over the last three years. Government pension plans can dig themselves into deeper holes because, unlike corporate pension plans, they are not bound by federal requirements to maintain a certain level of funding. Some have no reserves at all: they just pay as they go, out of revenues.
With money tight, municipalities are desperately looking for financial help. This year, pension bonds will account for nearly 5 percent of all new municipal bonds, up from less than 1 percent in each of the last five years.
In the first nine months of this year, Illinois, Oregon's school boards, New Jersey's economic development authority and more than a dozen towns and counties sold $13.3 billion in bonds for pension purposes, almost as much as the total sold for pensions throughout the 1990's, according to Thomson Financial, a research firm.
More sales are coming. Wisconsin and Oregon each plan one before the end of this year, and Kansas has authorized a sale. West Virginia, home of the nation's weakest public pension plan -- according to a study by Wilshire Associates, an investment advisory firm in Santa Monica, Calif., the state teacher's plan has only $1 for every $5 it owes -- is fighting a court battle to sell $3.9 billion of the bonds without first holding a referendum. In California, a planned $1.9 billion bond sale for state employees' pensions contributed to the fiscal uproar that led to the recall of Gov. Gray Davis.
Other officials have weighed the risk and declined. "It's really tough to justify," said Robert C. North, the chief actuary for New York City's five employee pension plans. For years, Mr. North said, investment bankers have been urging the city to sell bonds to pay for its pension promises, and every time, he argues against it because he believes there are sounder and cheaper ways of financing pensions. 
"On a risk-adjusted basis, the only people who can make money on this are the investment bankers," Mr. North said. 
This risk is not always made sufficiently clear, critics say, by financial consultants who stand to make money from the bond sales.
New Orleans recently found out just how deep a hole it had dug for itself by selling bonds in late 2000 to finance the pensions of 820 retired firefighters. In May, city officials asked the manager of the bond sale, UBS Financial Services, for a progress report and were shocked to learn that the deal was expected to cost the city $270 million over time.
"We were thinking that we were going to make money on it," said Suzy Mague, fiscal officer for the New Orleans city council.
City officials say their rosy expectations were created by PaineWebber, the lead underwriter, when it described the bond transaction. (PaineWebber, which collected a $3 million fee for its role in the bond sale, has since merged with UBS.) 
"It was basically presented to us as, 'Look, this is really the way to go. Even if you use the worst estimates, you still break even,' " said Scott Shea, a former city council member who served on the budget committee at the time.
According to Ms. Mague, PaineWebber said New Orleans would probably have to pay about 8.2 percent interest on the bonds. PaineWebber predicted that the city could expect to earn 10.7 percent a year, on average, by investing the proceeds, mostly in stocks, a prediction based on returns from 1983 to 1999 -- a period that encompassed the greatest bull market in history.
A spokeswoman for UBS said the company did include less favorable possibilities in its presentation, and did not suggest that 10.7 percent, or any other rate of return, was guaranteed.
Mr. Shea said he asked PaineWebber about risk. "I frankly don't recall anybody telling me, 'Look, if the market tanks, you'll be in worse shape than if you had never sold the bonds,' " he said.
New Orleans issued bonds worth $171 million in December 2000, and almost immediately, the stock market tanked. Instead of returning 10.7 percent a year, the investments have suffered losses of about 3 percent a year. 
By June, only $98 million was left -- enough to pay the firefighters' pensions for just a few more years. When the money runs out, the city will still have to pay their pensions -- about $17 million a year -- but then it will also have to pay interest on the bonds of $16 million a year.
Pittsburgh, likewise, sold $294 million of bonds in 1996 and 1998 to buttress a skimpy pension plan for its workers. Before that, the city was spending about $21 million a year from its operating budget to keep the plan afloat. 
After an initial spurt, the pension plan slumped again when stock prices fell. Today, Pittsburgh is paying $26 million a year to shore up the plan and to pay its bondholders. Two major credit-rating agencies recently said they were reviewing Pittsburgh and might lower its rating because of its heavy indebtedness.
New Jersey had similar results after issuing $2.8 billion of bonds in 1997. The sale was the largest of its kind then and made headlines by generating $53 million in fees for various securities and law firms. 
In the first two years, the transaction looked good. New Jersey earned more than double the break-even amount. Then the markets turned. As of June, the pension plan's five-year average return was 1.9 percent, nowhere near enough to cover the pension costs and bond interest, which this year totaled $890 million.
"This money didn't build a road or a bridge, but we still have to pay it," John E. McCormac, the state treasurer of New Jersey said.
Officials may look past unhappy outcomes like these in part because market conditions have improved. Stocks are rising. Interest rates are very low, and officials see an opportunity to lock in debt at historically attractive rates.
Even Orange County in California is considering an issue, despite lingering concerns over its bankruptcy proceedings in 1994.
The county got into trouble after taking on undue investment risk, something critics of the new issues fear will happen again as states reach for higher returns. New Jersey, for example, has restricted pension investments to stocks and bonds, but is reviewing its portfolio and whether to hire an independent money manager, as other states do. 
The state's auditor has recommended investing a small amount in alternative investments, perhaps real estate, venture capital or other instruments that may provide greater returns, at greater risk.. Some state employees oppose the change, saying the risks are too great.
Their view is supported by some government finance specialists and academics, who argue that speculative investments, even stocks, are unsuitable in pension funds. They say that people retire on predictable schedules, and it is safest to invest conservatively, in bonds that will mature when people need the money.
Depending on market conditions, though, the current crop of bonds could pay off handsomely for the governments issuing them.
An Illinois official says that the state's $10 billion bond issue was based on an assumption that the money would earn 8 percent to 8.5 percent annually. Illinois will pay 5.07 percent interest on the bonds. "As long as the actuaries are right," said a spokeswoman for the state budget bureau, "we should be safe."

HEADLINE: Big Corporations And Their Taxes 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article on recent changes to Connecticut's business tax ("Companies Prepare for New State Taxes," Sept. 21) tells a very small part of a very large story. Since Connecticut's deficit began in the summer of 2001, the state has enacted well over $1 billion in spending cuts, many of which fall most heavily on our children and their families. We have reduced health care coverage for kids, made deep cuts to affordable child care, decreased the state's contribution to K-12 education, reduced need based scholarships for higher education and more. 
 Many of these cuts would not have been necessary had we been willing to restore some of the hundreds of millions of corporate taxes that were drastically cut during the last decade. The business tax cuts were so steep that by 1999, 38 of Connecticut's 95 largest corporations paid no corporation business tax at all, and nearly two-thirds (more than 52,000 corporations) paid only the corporate Alternative Minimum Tax (A.M.T.) of $250. (Recent changes in the law require all corporations subject to the business corporation tax to pay at least the $250 A.M.T.) 
 As a share of total tax revenues, the Connecticut corporation business tax is now third lowest among states, yet Connecticut is home to General Electric Co. (recently ranked by The Wall Street Journal Market Data Group as the world's largest public company), United Technologies Corporation, and other very large corporations. The share of tax revenues coming from all of Connecticut's business taxes combined is now behind gambling as a source of General Fund revenues.
Connecticut has begun to renew some corporate tax responsibilities, but, as your article suggests, the state has not made appropriate distinctions between small and large businesses. For example, by adding a surtax to the corporation business tax, we have increased the taxes due from the many small and medium businesses that pay taxes here, but we have not touched the many, very large corporations, that because of tax breaks and loopholes, pay only the $250 A.M.T. There are many ways to make the corporate tax distribution fairer to small businesses that have not been adopted, in part because the best interests of the small business community are often overshadowed by big business interests in Hartford.
Asking corporations to share fairly in tax responsibility is sound public policy. Research on corporate location decisions shows that taxes are only one of many (and generally not one of the most important) factors in that decision making process. Last year, New Jersey adopted a multi-pronged corporation business tax reform despite claims that it would trigger a tremendous loss of employers and jobs from that state. A year later, key economic measures indicate that New Jersey fared better than Connecticut. The percentage increase in New Jersey's new business starts in the first quarter of 2003 compared with 2002 was twice that of Connecticut and New Jersey added 34,200 nonfarm jobs in March and April 2003 when Connecticut's net change was zero.
The general anti-tax message that has become so popular is short sighted. Businesses need and depend upon our roads, airports, rail lines, courts, educated workforce, health care system and more. All of these are paid for by tax dollars. As Franklin Delano Roosevelt said: Taxes are the dues we pay for the privileges of membership in an organized society.

Ellen Scalettar
Woodbridge

The writer is a senior policy fellow with Connecticut Voices for Children in New Haven and the director of Advocates for Connecticut's Children and Youth.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
SEGALL, JOEL E.

 BODY:
 SEGALL--Joel E. On October 9, 2003. Cherished husband of Joan; loving father of Patricia and son - in - law Michael; proud and devoted grandfather of Samuel, beloved brother of Sandra and Arlyne. 
An internationally known economist, he had successful careers in both government and higher education. He received his MBA, MA and PhD from the University of Chicago. After receiving his first graduate degree, he was appointed to the faculty of the University of Chicago Graduate School and ultimately became its Director of Doctoral Programs. During his 20 year tenure at Chicago, he held visiting appointments at various colleges including Stanford and Royal College of Science and Technology in Scotland. He left teaching for public service to hold key positions as Deputy Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy in the Treasury Department, then as Deputy Undersecretary for International Affairs in the Department of Labor. In both posts, he received departmental and secretarial awards. In 1977, he returned to higher education as President of Baruch College, a senior college in the City University of New York. In addition, Dr. Segall was a former Trustee of the United Nations Institute for Training and Research, a Director of Globe Security Insurance Company, a former member of the Board of Managers for Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York and former Chairman of Independent Trustees of the PIMCO Advisors Family of Mutual Funds. He has also directed many professional programs for the General Electric Foundation, Ford Foundation, McKinsey Foundation, and others. In 1995 he received the Professional Achievement Citation from the University of Chicago.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Warren Strugatch; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Proginet Corp. Posts a Loss Of $550,000 for Fiscal Year
The Proginet Corporation (OTC: PRGF) of Garden City has posted a loss of $550,376 for its fiscal year that ended July 31, reversing a profit of $196,614 recorded in the prior year. 
 Sales dropped from $6.6 million to $5.4 million, the company said in announcing the year's results on Monday. Proginet develops software for use in data security. 
 Kevin M. Kelly, the company's president and chief executive, said that despite declining sales, Proginet was able to improve its cash and liabilities position and had avoided assuming debt.
"Financial results fell short of the company's expectations for the fiscal year, yet the company was able to remain strong in a difficult economic climate," Mr. Kelly said.

Acclaim Raises $11.8 Million
Acclaim Entertainment (Nasdaq: AKLM) of Glen Cove, the developer of video games, said Monday that it had raised $11.8 million through a private sale of convertible notes, due in 2010. The money will be used for general corporate purposes, the company said.

Fonar to Sell Stock
The Fonar Corporation (Nasdaq: FONR) of Melville has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it planned to sell up to five million shares of common stock at a price to be determined when the shares are marketed.
Fonar, which designs and makes magnetic resonance imaging scanners, said it would use the money for operating expenses, including accounts payable.

Comverse Signs Contract
Comverse Technology (Nasdaq: CMVT) of Woodbury, which makes multimedia communications software, said Tuesday that it had signed a contract with Telefonos de Mexico to upgrade its voice-mail services. Comverse would not disclose the contract terms. 

Nu Horizons Agreement
The Nu Horizons Electronics Corporation (Nasdaq: NUHC) of Melville has signed a distribution agreement with Amphenol Worldwide. Nu Horizons, an electronics distributor, has agreed to sell Amphenol's line of coaxial connectivity products used in radio, microwave and data transmissions. Amphenol, a telecommunications manufacturer, is based in Wallingford, Conn. Compiled by Warren Strugatch

HEADLINE: He Told Them So 

BYLINE:  By John Aloysius Farrell; John Aloysius Farrell, the Washington bureau chief of The Denver Post, is the author of "Tip O'Neill and the Democratic Century."

 BODY:
 SENATOR MANSFIELD
The Extraordinary Life of a Great American
Statesman and Diplomat.
By Don Oberdorfer.
Illustrated. 593 pp. Washington:
Smithsonian Books. $32.95.
 THERE are parts of this fine new biography of Senator Mike Mansfield, as he pleads with Jack Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson not to plunge America into war in Southeast Asia, that could break your heart. Mansfield served with the Marines in China in 1922, then worked his way from the copper mines of Montana to become a college instructor, a congressman and the Senate's acknowledged expert on Asia. He never varied in the advice he gave about Indochina: the United States had no compelling national interest to defend there, and it would lose any war it chose to fight. Had he been able to persuade his two old friends, there might be no need for that black granite gash and its 58,000 names on the Mall in Washington. 
"We cannot hope to substitute armed power for the kind of political and economic social changes that offer the best resistance to Communism," Mansfield, then majority leader, wrote his friend President Kennedy about Vietnam in 1961. "If the necessary reforms have not been forthcoming over the past seven years to stop Communist subversion and rebellion, then I do not see how American combat troops can do it today." A year later, he warned that the United States was in danger of being drawn "inexorably" into the doomed role and bloody fate of the French colonial armies in Southeast Asia: "To ignore that reality will . . . be immensely costly in terms of American lives." Kennedy's face grew red with anger. "This is not what my advisers are telling me," he said.
Nor did Mansfield relent after Johnson, an ally of many years, replaced Kennedy in office. "The Communists are, obviously, not going to be faced down. It now appears that they are not going to be stung down. That leaves only the possibility of mowing them down and that is going to take a lot of time and a great many lives," he warned after the Pentagon reported that an American destroyer was attacked in the Gulf of Tonkin in 1964, and Johnson responded with bombing raids.
Toward the end of his 98 years, after capping a distinguished Senate career by serving two presidents as ambassador to Japan, Mansfield's voice still broke when he spoke of Vietnam. Like Oscar Schindler weeping for Jews he could not save, he found shame and tears in his failure to stop the killing. "It still haunts me," he told Don Oberdorfer, a former Washington Post reporter who teaches international relations at the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies, Johns Hopkins University. Though fond of his taciturn subject, in "Senator Mansfield" he doesn't duck the brutal question: Shouldn't the senator have gone public with his doubts, perhaps stepped down as Democratic leader in protest? Mansfield thought it better to preserve President Johnson's confidence, to ensure that the president got at least one expert and dissenting view. "I could have been more vigorous, I could have adopted another kind of procedure," Mansfield concedes in an interview. "But just don't know what it was." This is a thorough biography of a public man who served longer as majority leader than any other. It's perhaps a disservice to dwell so on Vietnam. Yet Oberdorfer recognizes Mansfield's role in the war as a core of the story. It is a timely topic.
The Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on the United States -- Mansfield lived to see them; he died a month later -- were no Tonkin Gulf incidents. There is little doubt that our national interest is now at stake: Ho Chi Minh didn't have hopes of acquiring pirated nuclear weapons or vials of smallpox, and could have been deterred if he had. Though the North Vietnamese fought with what we saw then as irrational commitment, Al Qaeda makes them look downright reasonable.
That said, it's instructive to weigh Mansfield's cleareyed prescriptions of how, and where, and in what proportion, the United States should best apply its military and economic power as it goes up against another guerrilla foe. Mansfield warned Kennedy that the United States was overreliant on military might, while shortchanging diplomacy and efforts to bring about social and economic reform. 
"The Vietnamese problem since 1955 has been a compound in which one part has been military and several nonmilitary," he told Kennedy in 1961. "Yet the remedy which has been applied to this problem has been a compound in which several parts have been military and only one part nonmilitary." In this season when another American intervention has etched a new place name -- Iraq -- on the gravestones at Arlington, it's a warning to which, this time, we should pay better attention.
