HEADLINE: Saudi Arabia's Big Leap 

BYLINE:  By Kenneth M. Pollack; Kenneth M. Pollack is director of research at the Saban Center for Middle East Policy at the Brookings Institution and a former director for Persian Gulf affairs at the National Security Council.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia's announcement on Monday that within a year it will hold elections for municipal councils could be the first tremor in a slow-moving Middle Eastern earthquake. 
 First, some caveats. We don't have all the details yet and, as things often do in the Middle East, this might not live up to its advance billing. A year is a long time away. The initiative might get derailed. The elections may not be as fair and free as promised. We do not know if women will be allowed to vote. And it is only a baby step toward addressing vast structural flaws within the Saudi system. 
 But still, the Saudi announcement is potentially a very big deal, and the cynics should take note: more so than even the pluralist maelstrom in Iraq, moves toward democratization in Saudi Arabia could have ripples throughout the Middle East. 
In fact, because Saudi Arabia is the most conservative of the Arab states, Riyadh's decision to start a process of democratization, no matter how gradual, is already beginning to force many Arabs to rethink where the tides of Middle Eastern history are headed. As long as the Saudis keep moving down this path, no matter how sluggishly, it will be hard for the other countries of the region not to follow. The other governments will have no answer when their people ask why, if the Saudis can adopt more pluralistic political institutions, can't they as well?
What's more, such reforms are the only way to deal with the two major threats that the United States faces from the dysfunctional Saudi system. The first is that Saudi society has become an important contributor to violent terrorist groups like Al Qaeda. Osama bin Laden himself is Saudi, and he has found many of his recruits among his disaffected young countrymen. And, knowingly or not, many wealthy Saudis -- including, probably, members of the royal family -- have contributed to Islamic charities that were fronts for terrorist organizations. 
The second threat is that much of the anger and frustration that makes Saudi Arabia a fertile recruiting ground for Osama bin Laden have also made Saudi internal politics increasingly volatile, raising the specter of a violent upheaval. As long as Saudi oil production remains a linchpin of the global economy, we cannot afford an Islamic revolution there. Even if civil war or a fanatical new regime did not shut Saudi oil production altogether, either might result in a reversal of the high-production, low-price oil policy that the Saudi royals adhere to. This would set off recessions around the globe.
Both of these threats spring, at least in part, from a common source: more than any other Arab state, Saudi Arabia is in desperate need of comprehensive political, economic, social, legal and educational reform. The economy is faltering badly, which in turn has meant that the kingdom can no longer afford the profligate ways of the royal family or the cradle-to-grave social welfare system erected during the fat years of the 1970's and 80's. The Saudi educational system is useless, emphasizing the humanities and Islamic studies at the expense of science and mathematics. Because of its reliance on rote memorization, even college graduates have few marketable job skills. Saudi Arabia's decrepit legal system is distorted by xenophobic strictures, like laws limiting foreign investment, and is undermined by abuses by the royal family. 
The result is that unemployment probably exceeds 30 percent, and among males in their 20's -- the talent pool for terrorists and revolutionaries -- it is probably even higher. No job means no income, no dignity, probably no wife, no sons and no place in Saudi society. Many of these angry young men focus their wrath at the autocratic Saudi regime, for not addressing these problems and for giving them no legal method of redress, and at the United States, for supporting that regime.
The only way for the Saudis to get at these deep-seated problems is through modernization, and that process has to start with the political system. Until there is greater transparency, accountability and participation in the political process, Riyadh will not be able to deal with the corruption and inertia that have paralyzed the economy and society. And as long as the royals are seen as running the kingdom purely for their own benefit, those preaching violent change will find plenty of willing executioners. 
So what can the United States do to see that Monday's announcement actually leads to something significant? 
First, we should endorse it, but not trumpet it. Crown Prince Abdullah, the leading reformist in the kingdom, and his supporters need to know that America appreciates what they are trying to do. Likewise, the opponents of reform among the royal family and the bureaucracy need to understand that Washington will hold accountable anyone who impedes change. However, the United States can't be seen by the Saudi public as embracing the effort too tightly -- Saudi demagogues would no doubt make political hay by claiming that anything America favors must be bad for Saudi Arabia.
Second, we may need to hold the Saudis' feet to the fire. We must make sure that electoral progress continues and is not an excuse for backsliding in other areas: legal reform, foreign ownership of Saudi businesses, educational reform and others. Yet Americans should keep in mind that the pace of reform is likely to be slow (if only because everything is slow in the kingdom) and that this is actually good for us and for them. As F. Gregory Gause III, a Saudi expert at the University of Vermont, has pointed out, if we could magically create democracy in Saudi Arabia tomorrow, we would probably find Islamic fundamentalists elected by overwhelming margins. It will take years of political liberalization before enough moderate political leaders emerge to offer an alternative to the Islamists and the regime.
In addition, we should come up with measures that might remove other pressures on Riyadh. Crown Prince Abdullah and his supporters will be loath to push electoral reforms if they face other problems at home. We could start with quiet conversations between Bush administration officials and members of the Saudi government to get a better feel as to how we can help them. For example, one good reason (among many) for the United States to work more vigorously with the Israelis and Palestinians is that the Saudi population's anger over the Arab-Israeli standoff has made the Saudi leadership cautious of taking actions that they expect could be unpopular.
But above all, we have to stay focused on our long-term priorities: shutting down terrorist financing and recruitment, supporting the reconstruction of Iraq and pursuing Saudi internal reform. Too often, we have saddled the Saudis with a host of other demands, from financing our pet projects (like Bosnian reconstruction) to purchasing expensive American military equipment, to lobbying members of the United Nations Security Council on our behalf. The more we press the Saudis on unpopular secondary issues, the slower they will move on terrorism and reform. And in the end, those are the issues that really endanger American interests and lives.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
In the Old Cities, Bitterness and Fleeting Joy

BYLINE:  By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
THERE is bitterness in Chicago today, with no redemption for the ancient franchise on the North Side.
 Alas, there is no reprieve for the horrified Cubs fan with the long arms, who will be blamed forever when, really, it was the Cubs who failed and the Marlins who succeeded. 
 Sometime tonight -- undoubtedly very late tonight -- there will be sorrow in another old baseball city, and joy in a third.
After enduring 24 hours of anguish over a dreadfully botched game Tuesday night, Chicago was knocked off last night by the arriviste Florida Marlins, 9-6, as the Cubs were once again denied their first pennant since 1945. 
Now it is time for either Boston or New York to ache. One of these two old protagonists will advance to the World Series, of which the Yankees have won 26 since the Red Sox last won one.
It had to come back to Roger and Pedro. 
The last time they met, allegedly grown men fought on the field and in the bullpen. Nobody wants any more of this buffoonery, but the tensions and the dust-ups have made for compelling baseball in the ballparks and in front of television sets and radios. 
As a consequence of yesterday's 9-6 victory by the Red Sox at wind-swept Yankee Stadium, Pedro Martinez of Boston and Roger Clemens of New York -- formerly of Boston -- will pitch tonight in yet another resumption of the ancient morality play. 
Both league championship series have been a thousand times more compelling because of who these old teams were. The fans shared these histories as they huddled and shivered elbow to elbow in chilly ballparks yesterday. 
In war and peace, generations of fans have suffered (or, in the Yankees' case, generally celebrated). In boom and recession, fans have taken the Green Line to Fenway Park, built in 1912; the Red Line to Wrigley Field, opened in 1914; and the D or No. 4 trains to Yankee Stadium, which opened in 1923.
The Marlins, by contrast, play in a square pastel stadium blatantly tailored for football, reachable by automobile. In every way, the Marlins were outsiders in these glorious days of baseball destiny.
Much is made of football's hold on the weekend attention span of America at this time of year. But baseball has been holding its postseason carnival every day for two full weeks. The television ratings say that the nation has been paying attention.
Hunkering in the dugout yesterday with a thick gray sweatshirt hood over his head was Pedro Martinez. He will be pitching to win, but he also needs to repair his image, which was tarnished last Saturday when he fired pitches at the Yankees, gestured and threatened, then tossed the onrushing 72-year-old Yankee coach, Don Zimmer, to the turf.
The brawls in Boston last Saturday and the bitterness in Chicago toward the hapless fan who reached for a catchable foul ball Tuesday have touched off a sense that all of us take this stuff far too personally. 
Yesterday, the Yankees had the august Bob Sheppard make an announcement asking the fans to respect one another "no matter what colors they may be wearing" and asking them to "root hard, have fun -- and be safe." Sheppard's voice sounded like a command from on high. And when Trot Nixon hit the home run that clinched the victory, Boston fans stood and cheered, and nobody mugged them.
The old cities quaked with the plots and subplots. The fans know all about long failures in Boston and Chicago, things that happened before any of the current players were born. It is one thing to yammer on about the ancient jinxes that afflict these hallowed teams representing two of America's greatest cities. It is quite another to watch bad things happen to them in public. 
There was Nomar Garciaparra, the superb Boston shortstop, fumbling a soft grounder yesterday to bring about two unearned runs. Ultimately he had four hits and scored two runs to disrupt the obsession in Boston over his slump. 
Fans in Chicago were screaming about the fan who reached for the foul ball that was heading into the stands in the eighth inning Tuesday. Normally, I am all for the weird curses and hexes, but in this case, I want everybody to lay off the guy. He was merely a civilian, unprepared to have the ball, the game, perhaps the season and probably even history, looping directly toward him.
What was the excuse for Chicago's shortstop, Alex Gonzalez, who booted a potential double-play ball that led to an eight-run rally by the Marlins? Who told the bullpen to give up all those hits? Baseball has a weird way of turning around, inning by inning, day by day.
The Red Sox, facing elimination yesterday, turned it around at the looming fortress in the South Bronx, the House That Ruth Built. The Red Sox have been perceived as having a more toxic curse than the Cubs' for having dispensed Babe Ruth to the Yankees. None of this history had much impact on the scruffy athletes with shaven heads who perform for the Red Sox. The reality is that the Yankees and the Red Sox will meet for a record 26th time this season. Pedro and Roger, all over again. 
While Chicago wallows in grief today, there is no guarantee that Boston can avoid the same disillusionment. These long streaks of suffering did not happen totally by accident. Baseball is having a terrific run of suspense and mood swings. There were no promises of redemption for these venerable franchises.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nomar Garciaparra forced out Hideki Matsui at second and threw to first to complete a double play on a ball hit by Nick Johnson in the seventh. (Photo by Barton Silverman/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 2265 words

HEADLINE: THEATER GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means discounted tickets were at the TKTS booth for last Friday night only.

Broadway

* "AVENUE Q." The inspired brainchild of the songwriters Robert Lopez and Jeff Marx, this canny toy chest of a musical takes its stylistic cues from "Sesame Street," from its cheery urban set to its singing puppets of assorted colors and dispositions. And in doing so it becomes the first mainstream musical since "Rent" to coo with such seductive directness to theatergoers on the fair side of 40 in their own language, in which irony is less a mind-set than a loosely worn style. Directed by Jason Moore, with a book by Jeff Whitty, the show applies the coaxing, learning-is-fun attitude of children's educational television to the R-rated situations of postcollegiate life in the big city. Featuring a pitch-perfect ensemble of live performers and oversize hand puppets, "Avenue Q" is to "Sesame Street" what Mel Brooks's "Producers" is to vintage Broadway musicals: a connoisseur's tribute to what it only seems to send up (2:10). John Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $46.25 to $91.25, with a limited number of $21.25 rush tickets by lottery at the theater at 5:30 p.m. for the evening show and at 11:30 a.m. for the matinee (Ben Brantley).

*++ "GYPSY." Playing a role that few people thought would ever fit her and shadowed by vultures predicting disaster, Bernadette Peters has delivered the surprise coup of many a Broadway season. This beloved eternal daughter of the American musical has taken on that genre's most daunting maternal role: Momma Rose, a part cast in bronze by Ethel Merman more than four decades ago. Directed by Sam Mendes, Ms. Peters has created the most complex and compelling portrait of her long career. In bringing new sensuality and self-awareness to Rose, Ms. Peters breaks the Merman mold but without distorting the near-perfect shape of a show assembled by the magical team of Arthur Laurents, Jule Styne and Stephen Sondheim. As a whole, Mr. Mendes's production may seem disappointingly status quo. But the brassy glories of the score and much of Jerome Robbins's original choreography are here to be savored as the stunning Ms. Peters casts new and haunting shadows on a familiar landscape. The fine supporting cast includes John Dossett and, in the title role, the coltish Tammy Blanchard (2:45). Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $61.25 to $101.25, with a limited number of $25 student rush tickets available Monday through Thursday evenings (Brantley).

++ "LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS." In the desperate, tourist-courting world of cultural appropriation on Broadway -- which has given us stillborn aberrations like "Saturday Night Fever" -- this bland revival of the 1982 musical does not rank as a major offender. It is directed with silky efficiency by Jerry Zaks. Howard Ashman's droll, cliche-bending lyrics and book -- about a florist's nerdy assistant who befriends a people-eating plant -- remain in place, as does Alan Menken's gleeful 1960's-pastiche score. There is also an array of personable, professional young talent, headed by Hunter Foster, Kerry Butler and Douglas Sills. Yet the show has been stripped of the urban grit and parodic wit of the downtown production of 21 years ago. The overall effect is, if not exactly pleasurable, then pleasant. As an exercise in recycling, the principal industry among Broadway producers now, this "Little Shop" suggests the conversion of sharp, shiny tin into something closer to Teflon (2:00). Virginia Theater, 245 West 52nd Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays at 7 p.m.; Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $56 to $96 (Brantley).

*+ "TAKE ME OUT" (Tony winner for best play). Playing a socially challenged money manager named Mason Marzac, Denis O'Hare (Tony winner for best featured actor in a play) shines with the gloom-dispelling wattage that comes when a first-rate actor meets a role he was born to play. When Mason talks about baseball (yes, baseball) in Richard Greenberg's comic drama, directed with verve by Joe Mantello (Tony winner for best director), the show emanates the dewy, delirious passion of a "Boheme" for the ESPN set. This story of pride and prejudice in professional sports, seen at the Public Theater last fall, has been advantageously shaved and streamlined for its Broadway incarnation. But in tracing the impact of a godlike baseball player (the perfectly cast Daniel Sunjata) who declares his homosexuality, Mr. Greenberg winds up sacrificing fully developed characters and plotting to Ideas with a capital I. Those notorious shower scenes remain, just so you know. Yet it is Mr. Greenberg's infatuation with baseball, ecstatically channeled by Mr. O'Hare, that makes this a show to cheer about (2:45). Walter Kerr Theater, 219 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $66 to $81 (Brantley).

Off Broadway

*+ "BECKETT/ALBEE." When Brian Murray and Marian Seldes get together in a play by Edward Albee, they seem to levitate like Astaire and Rogers. The easy elegance, the polished technique, the playfulness and the passion have been buffed to a high gloss in "Counting the Ways," Mr. Albee's blithely serious portrait of a marriage. Mr. Murray and Ms. Seldes perform a funny, deliberately stylized pas de deux that suggests a melding of Noel Coward and Samuel Beckett. In the show's first half, they take on Beckett himself in three short plays ("Not I," "A Piece of Monologue" and "Footfalls"). And it should be noted that they don't wear Beckett's tatters with quite the same assurance that they wear Albee's party clothes. But the evening offers a fascinating counterpoint of two playwrights of shared sensibility and contrasting styles (1:30). Century Center for the Performing Arts, 111 East 15th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $65, with a limited number of $20 student tickets available at the box office on the day of the performance (Brantley).

* "THE HARLEQUIN STUDIES." Bill Irwin's sweet, silly and sharp-witted anatomy of the clown figure from commedia dell'arte suggests that every comic working today should call the long-lived Harlequin "Papa." Mr. Irwin and a nimble ensemble of actors-cum-acrobats spring out of trunks, fall from the skies and are improbably packed into small suitcases, evoking everyone from Charlie Chaplin to Jim Carrey along the way. The show, which begins a season of Mr. Irwin's work from the Signature Theater Company, may not be the most accomplished work to date from its creator, the inspired silent clown of "The Regard of Flight" and "Fool Moon." But there is an endearing openness and generosity about the production, which features Rocco Sisto and Paxton Whitehead as well as five younger clowns-in-training. And in an anarchic and uncertain world, Mr. Irwin confidently locates a special, enduring kind of anarchy that pulls form out of chaos (1:15). Signature Theater's Peter Norton Space, 555 West 42nd Street, (212) 244-7529. Wednesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $55 (Brantley).

+ "LIVING OUT." Lisa Loomer's play tries hard to apply the conventions of the 30-minute sitcom to a two-hour play with serious intentions. The situation is knotty, complicated and all too familiar. Ana Hernandez (Zilah Mendoza), a young Latina in Los Angeles, works as a nanny for Nancy Robin (Kathryn Meisle), a young Anglo lawyer. Social and emotional complications pile up. The time Ana spends with Nancy's daughter means she has scant time for her own son. Nancy starts to fear she knows less about her own child than Ana does. The two women are forced into a kind of intimacy, but class and nationality impose a still greater distance. Ms. Loomer has an eye for the topical, and an ear for laugh lines. The production, directed by Jo Bonney, is sleek and moves quickly. But when more depth is required, the writing fails and the direction falters (2:15). Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43rd Street, (212) 246-4422. Tuesdays at 7 p.m.; Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $55, with a limited number of $10 student rush tickets available at the box office 30 minutes before the performance (Margo Jefferson).

* "MATT AND BEN." A superior brand of Hollywood bashing, written and performed by two young actresses, Brenda Withers and Mindy Kaling, this deliciously spiteful comedy sends up the movies' naked emperors in general and Matt Damon and Ben Affleck in particular. The two actresses play the title characters on the very brink of their fame, but in this version of the story, "Good Will Hunting" wasn't written by Matt and Ben; it literally fell, a manuscript fully composed and wrapped in brown paper, from the ceiling in Ben's apartment. The play depicts the two guys as competitive knuckleheads: Ben (Ms. Withers) is the vacuous good-time guy, Matt the unbearably earnest do-right. As they debate whether to take their gift from the movie gods as their own, the play makes intermittent flashbacks to tell their history. It's as sophomoric a plot setup as can be, but the play succeeds because as writers and actors, Ms. Kaling and Ms. Withers have a fine deadpan sense of both the absurd and the vicious (1:30). P.S. 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101. Mondays through Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays at 7 and 10 p.m. Tickets: $25, Mondays through Thursdays; $30, Fridays and Saturdays; $18 tickets with student identification (Bruce Weber).

+ "THE NIGHT HERON." Deception, betrayal and assorted acts of violence are enlisted in the pursuit of poetry, of all things, in this new offering from the exciting young playwright Jez (Mojo) Butterworth. Set in a shack in the Cambridgeshire Fens, the play follows the self-sabotaging attempts of two unemployed gardeners (Chris Bauer and Clark Gregg) and an ex-convict (Mary McCann) to win a cash prize for best poem. At the same time, they are searching for rhyme and reason in a brutal, random universe. That their chances of succeeding are heartbreakingly slim doesn't keep them from being a very entertainingset of losers. Directed by Neil Pepe, the production is stronger on comic surface than tragic depths, and the play ultimately chokes on its own ambitions. But it offers a bracing testament to the strength and originality of Mr. Butterworth's theatrical imagination (2:20). Atlantic Theater Company, 336 West 20th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $45 (Brantley).

*+ "OMNIUM GATHERUM." This lively surreal satire, about a celebrity-studded dinner party given by a fluttery Martha Stewart-like hostess, turns out to be something more than a glib intellectual lampoon. Line by line, "Omnium" -- written by Theresa Rebeck and Alexandra Gersten-Vassilaros -- doesn't provide much that's new. The weighter subjects under discussion, which range from American imperialism to the roots of terrorism, have surely been pondered by every thinking American since Sept. 11, 2001. But though it unfolds as a point-counterpoint debate, the play never feels merely schematic. Tragedy and triviality, ponderousness and pettiness are mixed into a salad so deliriously tossed that you can't separate the individual ingredients. The strength of the play, energetically staged by Will Frears, is in its sloppiness, a sense that orderly boundaries -- even between the living and the dead -- have been blurred into chaos. The endearingly manic Kristine Nielsen leads the vibrant cast (1:30). Variety Arts Theater, 110 Third Avenue, at 13th Street, East Village, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $66.25 (Brantley).

Last Chance

"THE DUTCH HEART OF MAN." You know this guy, right? That big lug with the killer's mitts and the little-boy-lost expression? He's been hanging around as long as actors have been wearing dirty T-shirts on stages and screens, always unaware of his own clumsy strength and searching for a good woman's love. This gentle giant shows up as a construction company employee named Dutch in Robert Glaudini's new play. Played by Salvatore Inzerillo, he talks to himself more than his predecessors did and has more foul-mouthed friends. Otherwise, he could slide right into a black-and-white movie of 50 or 60 years ago. This well-acted exercise in blue-collar deja vu, directed by Charles Goforth, is a production of the exciting Labyrinth Theater Company (1:30). Shiva Theater, Joseph Papp Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 239-6200. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $25, with a limited number of $15 tickets available at the box office 30 minutes before the performance (Brantley).

SECTION: Section F; Column 1; Escapes; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 1341 words

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
Weekender Germantown, N.Y.

BYLINE:  By KATHRYN MATTHEWS 

 BODY:
THE charms of Germantown are not immediately apparent. A cluster of modest homes, auto-body shops and an imposing public school dot the brief stretch of Route 9G that runs through the center of the township. At the intersection of 9G and Main Street, three gas stations compete, evoking the feel of a strip mall more than a rural idyll.
 But wend west toward the Hudson River or east into the hills, and the landscape that emerges in Germantown -- about two hours north of Manhattan in the southwest corner of Columbia County -- is the one that inspired the 19th-century landscape artist Frederic Edwin Church to build his estate, Olana, a few miles up the road. 
 "Our view is the money shot that everyone talks about -- when the sun sets behind the Catskills, it creates a mystical backlighting that is impossible to experience elsewhere," said Michael Pierce, an architect based in Manhattan, who, with his wife, Elizabeth Dougherty, a freelance art director, lives part time in Germantown. "You can't get it in Rhinebeck, in towns beyond Hudson, or across the river in the Catskills." 
Mr. Pierce and Ms. Dougherty had not planned to buy a house in Germantown. But the sweeping backyard vistas of the Hudson and the Catskills from the house, which was built in 1890, lured them, and they bought it in 2001 as their third home.
Germantown, settled in 1710, was a farming community for most of its history. "When I was growing up, Germantown was known for their apple, pear and cherry trees," recalled Margarite Riter, 77, Germantown's historian. Few of the orchards remain. Today it is primarily a bedroom community, with many of its full-time residents commuting to government jobs in Albany, Kingston and Poughkeepsie.

The Scene
All over town, weekenders and full-time residents live side by side, with large private houses sometimes adjacent to trailer homes. Though there is not much social crossover, relations are generally friendly, and no one is putting on airs. "Everyone dresses the same," Mr. Pierce said of the low-maintenance dress code -- pullovers, khakis and rugged footwear.
Germantown's affluent weekenders -- among the residents whose comings and goings attract neighborly curiosity are Sonny Rollins, the jazz musician, and Pierre Levai, the director of the Marlborough Gallery -- tend to be reclusive. But even they are likely to venture into the Central Market on Main Street, which is also the center for town news and gossip.
Last year, Central's longtime owner, Lee Filiberti, went into partnership with Gary Capetta, a commercial real estate broker, and Nick Jones, a marketing and events specialist, who both patronized the store after buying their riverside weekend farmhouse in 1998. They have upgraded and expanded the store's inventory. It's like a "mini Balducci's," Mr. Pierce said.
For the most part, finding entertainment or dining out means leaving Germantown, which has no restaurants. There is plenty of music, theater and dance about 15 minutes away in Hudson or at the new performing arts center at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson.

Pros
Weekenders extol Germantown's relaxed style and low-key sensibility. "There's no pretension or hysteria here," said Susan Seidel, an art dealer from the Upper East Side of Manhattan. "If I wandered into Central Market with clumps of mud in my hair from gardening, nobody would look twice at me."
Residents have good access to the Hudson. There are two free public boat launching sites: Cheviot Park and the larger, more popular Anchorage in North Germantown. Fishing is allowed at both.
Outdoor enthusiasts find plenty to occupy them. Two state historic sites, the Moorish-style Olana and Clermont, once the home of the Livingston family, are open year-round and have trails for hiking and cross-country skiing. Hunter and Windham Mountains, with downhill skiing, are a half-hour drive away, and there is swimming at Lake Taghanic State Park, a 15-minute drive to the east.
Germantown's hill-and-dale terrain attracts cyclists, who loop around the pretty country roads. "It's almost a semiprofessional sport around here," Mr. Pierce said.

Cons
Two plants on the Hudson directly across from the town -- Glens Falls Lehigh Cement in Cementon and St. Lawrence Cement in Catskill -- break the otherwise ideal river view. Of concern to many Germantown residents is Glens Falls Lehigh's plan to expand operation up to 8,760 hours a year, which received final approval from the New York Environmental Conservation Department on Oct. 3. "This translates into 24 hours a day, 365 days a year," said Larry Osgood, vice president of the recently formed Germantown Neighbors Association.

The Real Estate Market
Property values have steadily increased about 8 to 10 percent a year since 1991, according to Ralph Delpozzo, owner of Ralph's Country Realty in Germantown. This year he expects a 20 percent jump from 2002, despite the slow economy. Properties that were priced at $200,000 and $400,000 a year ago are now 20 to 30 percent higher, he said.
Strong demand has limited the housing stock. There are 15 properties listed, with prices ranging from $147,000 to $1.5 million. They include 10 three-bedroom houses, with an average asking price of $315,000. What is available tends to sell in three to six months, said Patricia A. Hinkein, who owns an agency under her name in Germantown.
Though styles run the gamut, from farmhouses to contemporaries, most people seeking second homes hope to own an old house on several acres with stellar views. Riverfront properties, especially, are in high demand but short supply.
Increasingly, scarcity has caused more people to buy land for building. "There's been a real upsurge in new construction over the past two years," Ms. Hinkein said. "With few exceptions, Germantown zoning requires that lot sizes be at least one to two acres. However, most lots are much larger these days, reflecting a desire for privacy, particularly among existing second-home parcels and new construction."
Her listings includea 1,856-square-foot, three-bedroom village Victorian, circa 1900, on a third of an acre in the village center, for $170,000; a two-story, two-bedroom log contemporary on 3.6 acres with Catskills views, for $375,000; and a 3,600-square-foot, five-bedroom 1830 center-hall colonial on 3.5 acres, with a stream, for $500,000. Another is a 5,000-square-foot, six-bedroom 1755 stone house once owned by the Rockefellers. On six acres, it has two barns and country views and is next to a 144-acre bird sanctuary. It is offered at $1.2 million.

LAY OF THE LAND
The Right Place For Serious Quiet

POPULATION -- 2,018.
SIZE -- 12.5 square miles.
MEDIAN HOUSE PRICE -- $250,000.
RECENT SALES -- A 1,500-square-foot, three-bedroom 1970 ranch on one acre sold in September for $149,900, the asking price, after two days on the market; a 1,728-square-foot, two-bedroom cottage on 1.6 acres sold for $315,000 in July, down from its original $329,000 listing price, after 10 months on the market; a 2,500-square-foot, four-bedroom 1879 Victorian, with six acres and Hudson River and Catskills views, sold for $485,000, the asking price, in August, after five months on the market.
DISTANCE FROM NEW YORK -- 120 miles.
TRAVEL TIME -- About two hours in light traffic. By rail, an hour and a half on Amtrak from New York to Rhinecliff ($29 one way), about a 20-minute drive from Germantown.
GETTING THERE -- Take the Taconic State Parkway north to the Red Hook-Route 199 exit. Turn left on Route 199 and continue west about 10 miles until Route 199 intersects with Route 9G. Turn right onto Route 9G, driving about nine miles to the traffic light at the intersection of 9G and Main Street and turn right.
WHILE YOU'RE LOOKING -- The Gingerbread Haus (44 Young America Road, 518-537-3756), a two-story unit, accommodates up to four guests in a party. Rates are $125 a night on weekends and $95 on weekdays. The Inn at Blue Stores Bed and Breakfast in Livingston (2323 Route 9, 518-537-4277) is a 1908 farmhouse with five rooms. Rates are $150 to $225, with a two-night minimum.

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Column 3; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 921 words

HEADLINE: ON STAGE AND OFF 

BYLINE:  By Jason Zinoman 

 BODY:
What's Next? Skyboxes?
 Seeing a show on Broadway can be exciting, glamorous or, frankly, boring, but it is rarely comfortable. Long lines, cramped seats and crowded restrooms are not what most people would expect with a $100 purchase, but that's the reality in most of Broadway's historic houses. 
 Last night, at the first preview of Richard Greenberg's "Violet Hour," the audience at the elegantly renovated Biltmore Theater could expect to sink into wide camel-colored chairs with high wood backs. Any latecomers stuck in the lobby wouldn't have to crane their necks to eavesdrop behind closed doors because they could watch the drama on video monitors on three different floors. 
At intermission, customers could walk down a wide aisle toward the spacious new restrooms below the orchestra level or the smaller ones on the upper level.
"From the very beginning, we wanted to give audiences a comfortable, hospitable experience," said Barry Grove, executive producer of the Manhattan Theater Club, which has taken over the Biltmore. "We don't want them to just come for the play. We also want them to enjoy the theater." With multiplexes offering La-Z-Boy-size seating and sports stadiums packed with corporate skyboxes, today's theatergoers expect more upscale amenities with their entertainment.
Some theater owners have adjusted with the times. At the Imperial, the Shubert Organization expanded the restrooms and upgraded the seats (still not as luxurious as those at the Biltmore) before last night's opening of "The Boy From Oz" (review, Page 1 of Weekend).
While it's unlikely that skyboxes will replace the cheap seats on Broadway, the new Biltmore does have an exclusive Patron's Lounge on the second floor, where donors of $1,500 or more receive free wine and coffee, not to mention access to their own private restrooms.
The Roundabout Theater Company's American Airlines Theater and the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center offer similar perks, but they cost more: $2,000 to enter the Beaumont's Sondra and Charles Gilman Jr. Patron's Room, or $1,750 for the privilege of drinking wine and munching on Oreos and Fig Newtons in the Roundabout's Nabisco Lounge.

'Taboo' Scramble
Is there a show doctor in the house? There is at the Plymouth Theater, where "Taboo" is scrambling to get ready for opening. Yesterday, eight days before the scheduled first previews, the producer, Rosie O'Donnell, has brought Jeff Calhoun, the Broadway choreographer ("Bells Are Ringing," "Annie Get Your Gun") and sometime director (the recent revival of "Big River," the 1994 revival of "Grease"), on board as a "choreographic consultant." Is this a sign of trouble for the $10 million musical? For now, no one's talking. "It speaks for itself," said John Barlow, the show's press representative.

Send In the Stars
" 'Inside the Actor's Studio' as a musical" is the way Glen Roven described "Singular Sensations," a weekly series of conversations with musical-theater greats that begins on Nov. 3 at the Village Theater. In a collection of weeklong runs, Mr. Roven, a veteran composer and musical director, will talk to stars including Carol Channing (Nov. 3 to 9), Elaine Paige (Dec. 8 to 14), Betty Buckley (Jan. 5 to 11), Mickey Rooney (Jan. 12 to 18) and Cy Coleman (Jan. 27 to Feb. 1), each of whom may occasionally interrupt the interview and break into song.
In other openings, Tony Randall's National Actor's Theater's next production will be "Right You Are," Pirandello's philosophical comedy (with an abbreviated title). Written four years before "Six Characters in Search of an Author," the play follows a mysterious family who move into town, inspiring speculation among the neighbors. Mr. Randall stars. Previews begin on Nov. 25 at the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University in Lower Manhattan.

Doll Gets a Chill
Randall L. Wreghitt, a producer of the ever-gestating Broadway production of "Paper Doll," has a problem. And it's not just the recent dropout of a valued investor, which forced the show to postpone its opening, scheduled for Dec. 8, for the second time. (The play was originally supposed to come to Broadway last spring.)
Currently, his most pressing problem is a small Off Broadway drama called "Frozen" at the MCC Theater that is threatening to steal away the valuable time of his star, Swoosie Kurtz. "Frozen," by Bryony Lavery, also starring Ms. Kurtz, starts rehearsals on Jan. 26 and begins previews one month later for a seven-week run. If Ms. Kurtz is to going to fit "Paper Doll" into her schedule before "Frozen," Mr. Wreghitt will have to raise some money fast.

Teary-Eyed Comics
And then the laughter stopped. After 23 years and more than 8,500 performances, the downtown comedy institution Chicago City Limits is calling it quits. Paul Zuckerman, an original cast member of the improv troupe and its artistic director, broke the news to the cast in a teary meeting last Friday.
"We were five months behind on rent, and Con Ed was threatening to discontinue service," Mr. Zuckerman said. "The hole just got bigger and bigger, and I couldn't dig anymore." Mr. Zuckerman blamed the economy, which since 9/11 has slowed group sales and the influx of cash from corporate entertainment. The last show is to be on Nov. 2.

Not All Is True
Two stars of the small screen, Erika Alexander ("Living Single") and Phylicia Rashad ("The Cosby Show"), are to appear in "The Story," Tracey Scott Wilson's new play about journalistic ethics (and the lack thereof), opening at the Public Theater on Dec. 10.

LENGTH: 2007 words

HEADLINE: JOURNEYS; 
Small Courses, Heavy Hitters

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
TOM DIXON tossed his ball in the pond, the one by the statue of the giraffe. That's how frustrated Mr. Dixon, a former rodeo rider and long-haul trucker, was by his abysmal score of 40 in his morning's round of the Masters National Pro MiniGolf Championship. "If one of them doesn't work for me, it's history," he said. 
 Serious stuff, minigolf. At least at the Masters, being played on the greens of the 18-hole Hawaiian Rumble course on a stretch of Highway 17 just north of the resort town of Myrtle Beach, S.C. Don't confuse it with that other Masters in Augusta, Ga., a few hours' drive to the south. Actually, there's not much chance of that, since even a child knows the difference between golf and minigolf. The volcano is the first clue. 
 On any normal day, the 40-foot-tall faux Mauna Loa at the Hawaiian Rumble course belches smoke and, every 20 minutes, erupts with roaring pyrotechnics. Bob Detwiler, the gray-haired impresario of the United States Pro MiniGolf Association and, not coincidentally, owner of the Hawaiian Rumble and two other area courses on which the championship was played, said the eruptions might distract the players so "we turned it off." The volcano just smokes, sulking. 
Some 50 minigolfers from around the neighborhood -- and around the world -- have come here to play for a title that might make people unfamiliar with this world scratch their heads in bemusement. They are playing for a minipurse -- a $4,000 first prize -- tip money compared with the more than $1 million Mike Weir took home for winning Augusta's Masters earlier this year.
Still, winning this Masters is special. "Right here -- this is it," Mr. Dixon said. And it's about more than the money, Mr. Detwiler said. "We have a green jacket like they do at Augusta." Then he paused. "It's not a sports coat. It's a windbreaker, with gold lettering. It is green." 
For those who haven't played a round lately, it may come as a surprise, but miniature golf is anything but small these days. And what folks in this world tend to refer to as "big golf" has been struggling recently, with the number of rounds played dropping to 502.4 million last year from a peak of 518.4 million in 2000, according to the National Golf Foundation. New course development has fallen by nearly 50 percent in the same period.
But minigolf has boomed: Major tournaments make it onto morning television and minigolf organizations worldwide are making a credible run at getting their sport into the Olympics. Meanwhile, course-development companies are feeling flush. Harris Miniature Golf, a company that designs and builds courses, said that business has been strong even through an economy that has hammered other markets. "We've been steady for the last four or five years," said Sophia Disney, the company's marketing director, with as many as 50 new courses a year being built. 
Builders like Joe Rogari, vice president of Mini-Golf Inc., which can put one in for as little as $15,000, say business is up as much as 60 percent since 1997. "Sometimes when the economy is bad, it might help us a little bit," Mr. Rogari said, because "people are always looking for an inexpensive recreational activity." Minigolf, he noted, can be an alternative to that "Caribbean vacation or a cruise."
But the field is anything but peaceable. No fewer than three professional organizations run tournaments, and none has much use for the others. "We all have different goals and different objectives," said Paul Hemingway, head of the Professional Miniature Golf Association, a network for course owners. Joseph Aboid, commissioner of the Professional Putters Association, with courses that resemble putting greens, put it this way: "Putt-Putt is a game of skill, and miniature golf is a game of chance -- it doesn't take much skill to have a ball go into an alligator's mouth and come out on the other side."
That's a bit unfair, since Mr. Detwiler's offerings are pretty sophisticated compared with the wacky courses of yore. There are no windmills or seals standing between the players and the hole these days; just obstacles like a strategically placed stone that forces a bank shot, or the undulations of a course that can drop more than 30 feet from tee to hole. The kitsch hasn't been banished completely -- it's just been moved to the sidelines, as in the statues of zoo animals and the waterfalls at the Hawaiian Caverns course, also owned by Mr. Detwiler, or the dancing hippos that grace the Fantasia Gardens course at Walt Disney World in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. 
Though many "big" golfers still disparage the mini game, fans of the new short courses say they actually help improve their putting skills. That's what attracted John Asher, an avid golfer from Paris, Ky., who made this Masters his first tournament. "It's like they say: 'drive for show, putt for dough,' " he drawled.
Lane Helms, from Holden Beach, N.C., who drove 40 miles to join the tournament, agreed. "It's helped my regular golf game a lot," he insisted, standing under a Tiki hut near a giraffe statue. The owner of a garage-door company, Mr. Helms was making his fifth appearance at the mini Masters. "I guarantee" -- stretching out each syllable, pronouncing it gare-on-tee -- "it's just as competitive out here as in big golf." And besides, you can play a round in just 45 minutes. 
Elsewhere on the course, an 8-year-old sprite named Olivia Prokopva popped the golf ball along the green carpet with a surehandedness that seemed preternatural. She is a favorite in the minigolf world who has traveled from her home in the Czech Republic throughout Europe and the United States. A bona fide mini prodigy, she swept the juniors division of the United States Open in 2002 and 2003 and the Masters National Championship in 2002, and won third place over all in the women's division at the U.S. Open in 2003. "That little child is phenomenal," the tournament director, Bo Taylor, said.
Olivia wore greatness lightly, and sized up the shots with cool calculation, guided by an entourage that included her trainer; her father, Jan Honza Prokop; and her younger brother. Mr. Prokop brought over her scrapbook with newspaper clippings that show Olivia is a celebrity back home: score cards and tournament programs, photographs of her on the family's basement putting green, and with Czech entertainers and the nation's president, Vaclav Klaus. 
The European players approach the game with a fixedness of purpose that can unnerve the more happy-go-lucky Americans. Members of the Swedish team that has taken the world championships in Europe included the sunburned Hans Olofsson, from Stockholm. At Hawaiian Rumble, he carefully scanned each green, planning the shot and executing with near-mechanical precision. When he made a tough putt, like one that required banking the ball off the brick border of the green for a hole in one, he raised his putter into the air in quiet triumph, an all but inaudible "Yah" escaping his lips.
Karl Lakos, a tall, tough-looking Austrian, stared at the ball so hard that it was a little surprising it did not burst into flames. "They take their miniature golf truly, phenomenal serious," Mr. Taylor said.
Many of the American competitors, on the other hand, balance their competitive drive with a taste for the pleasures minigolf has to offer. In Myrtle Beach, those include the panorama of beachwear stores, tacky restaurants and billboards for strip clubs that line Highway 17. "This is what our boys are fighting for in Iraq," said Peter Gilchrist, who came in from Boothbay Harbor, Me., with his wife, Nancy. He was kidding, sort of. 
AT the end of the last round, Olivia was on the last hole and suddenly developed a killer case of the yips. The girl who sank a hole in one on the Hawaiian Caverns toughest green -- the one with three drops and an acute-angled left turn that only five other players have ever gotten in a single stroke -- took five strokes to sink a relatively straightforward putt. For a moment, she actually looked her age, pouting and fragile and very vulnerable. A lesser 8-year-old would have stormed off; actually, a lesser 8-year-old would have lost interest in the game after the first round. Her trainer stood by, chagrined. Her father, sitting on a bench across a pond, shouted encouragement, or maybe something else. And then he rested his forehead against his hands.
Meanwhile, Mr. Dixon played the ball off of a gentle rise at the left so that when the course doglegged to the right, the ball curved around and down toward the hole as though it were looking for it. He smiled; this ball wasn't going in any pond.
Still, he was having problems. In his previous competitive career on the rodeo circuit, Mr. Dixon said, he broke every bone in his body, including his neck -- twice -- while very large animals kicked him in the face, stepped on his back and, fairly regularly, threw him to the ground.
Now, with the skies over Myrtle Beach brooding with rain, his bones were aching. His doctor recommends he have an operation to relieve strain along his spine. But he would rather put it off. "I'm trying to stay away from surgery," Mr. Dixon said. "This is my season."
But not, in the end, his day. 
After 14 rounds, Mr. Dixon finished in 30th place, at 522 strokes for the total 252 holes, 75 strokes out of the money. Olivia did slightly better, with a total score of 511. That was good enough to take the juniors division, and to put her in 23rd place over all, 64 strokes behind the eventual winner, Danny McCaslin of Morrisville, N.C. Mr. McCaslin, who works as a waiter and bartender at an Olive Garden restaurant, triumphed over his nearest rival, Mr. Olofsson, by five strokes. It was Mr. McCaslin's second championship win -- he took first place at the U.S. Open in May. But he shrugged off any pretension about the title. All it meant, he said, was that he was the national champion -- "of something."
"You know," he added, "you've just got to keep it all in perspective."

PLAYING THROUGH
No Fairways, Just Greens: Where Putts Rule

MINIGOLF courses have become less about windmills and more about banked shots and rolling terrain. Here, some notable courses around the country.

AUGUSTA PUTT PUTT
3763 Martinez Boulevard, Martinez, Ga., (706) 868-0083; www.augustaputtputt.com
THE COURSE -- Down the road from the "other" Masters at Augusta National. Two 18-hole putting courses (all holes are par 2) with waterfalls and animals (plus bumper boats for nongolfers). The Professional Putters Association National Championship was there last year.

CAROUSEL FAMILY FUN CENTER
4 David Drown Boulevard, Fairhaven, Mass., (800) 870-4828; www.carouselskate.com
THE COURSE -- Located not far from Cape Cod, this 18-hole, par 43 course has a nautical theme and rivers running through it. The Massachusetts Open will be played here tomorrow. Closes Oct. 26.

CREEKSIDE FAMILY GOLF COURSE AT LOS ABRIGADOS RESORT & SPA
160 Portal Lane, Sedona, Ariz., (928) 282-1777; www.ilxresorts.com
THE COURSE -- 18-hole, par 40 course runs along the banks of Oak Creek. Play is accompanied by the sounds of music -- pop songs during the day; Mozart, Chopin and Beethoven at night. The course is a part of Premiere Country Club at the resort, which has full-swing virtual golf that plays 33 different courses including St. Andrews and Pebble Beach.

DEER RUN GOLF CENTER
11007 West Route 120, Woodstock, Ill. (815) 338-9701
THE COURSE -- Par 42, 18-hole "adventure" course has a mountain, a waterfall and a Wild West theme (coyotes, tombstones, rock outcroppings). The front nine is accessible by wheelchair. For die-hard players, Roy Dombeck, its golf pro, has had to clear ice out of the holes.

DISNEY'S FANTASIA FAIRWAYS AT WALT DISNEY WORLD RESORT
1205 North Epcot Resort Boulevard, Lake Buena Vista, Fla., (407) 560-4870; www.disneyworld.com
THE COURSE -- This 18-hole course (par 61; course record, 50) has "big golf" touches like sand traps and water hazards. Includes par 3 and par 4 holes. Adjacent child-scaled Fantasia Gardens course has characters and music from the film.

SECTION: Section B; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 576 words

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
No Price Bubble in Region's Housing, Study Concludes

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
It's not a bubble, so it won't burst.
 That, essentially, is the conclusion of an economic study of the current housing market in the New Jersey, New York and Connecticut region by two professors at Rutgers University. Using the home-price plunge of the late 80's for comparison, they have calculated that price increases for single-family homes in the region in the last five years have not been excessive. 
 The report, "Housing Bubble or Shelter -- Safe Haven?" states: "The regional housing market is not about to suffer a collapse. The bursting of the housing bubble in 1988 will remain a subject of history, not a predictor of our housing future." The study was written by James W. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, and Joseph J. Seneca, a professor of economics at the Bloustein school. 
In the 1980's, Dr. Hughes said in an interview, "We did have an extraordinary ratcheting up of housing prices and then a very severe price setback during the '89-'92 recession."
Between 1983 and 1988, home prices in New Jersey rose by 109 percent, the report found. In Connecticut, they jumped by 120 percent. In New York, because of a stagnant economy upstate, the increase was a more modest 76 percent. Those increases far outpaced the national rate of 37 percent.
"They were not sustainable," Dr. Hughes said. And in the ensuing recession, they retreated 7.8 percent in New Jersey, 18 percent in Connecticut and 4.5 percent in New York.
It would take until 1998 in New Jersey and New York and 2000 in Connecticut for home prices to climb back to their 1988 peak. "What that suggests," Dr. Hughes said, "is that economic wild parties are followed by prolonged hangovers." Those calculations do not account for a 32 percent rise in inflation between 1988 and 1998, meaning that in real dollars, prices in 1998 remained 30 percent below their 1988 peak.
The study goes on to point out that price increases in the last five years have been far more modest than those during the five-year bubble of the 80's. In New Jersey, they increased by 52 percent between 1998 and 2002; in New York, by 53 percent, and in Connecticut by 44 percent. By comparison, housing prices across the nation increased by 38 percent in the same period.
So the current price gains were far less than those in the 1980's, the report found. And the gap between the three states and the nation was considerably smaller. "Therefore," Dr. Hughes said, "it's hard to make a case, at least on a statewide basis, that the price increases of the last five years have been excessive."
The study then addressed the factors that have supported the price rises of the last five years. "No. 1 is that by 1998," Dr. Hughes said, "the financial position of many households was bolstered by stock market gains, whether it was their 401(k)'s or even if they just owned mutual funds. Given that supposed financial security, people were willing to spend more on housing." 
At the same time, mortgage interest rates dropped from 8 percent in 2000 to 5.5 percent in 2003 -- a 45-year low. Then, in March 2000, the stock market plummeted. "And that made housing even more desirable," Dr. Hughes said. "It was seen as the safe port in the economic storm."
The report concludes: "All of the gains in housing-purchasing power as a result of interest-rate reductions in the current market probably have been made. So upward pressure on prices is bound to diminish."
